member.name: T:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Implementation.Generic.GenericLapack`1
member.summary: Implements a subset of the LAPACK linear algebra package for generic element types.
member.typeparam: The element type of the arrays.

summary.para: Multiplies an n-element complex vector x by the real scalar 1/a.

param.name: n
param.pre: The number of components of the vector x.

param.name: sa
param.pre: The scalar a which is used to divide each component of x. SA must be >= 0, or the subroutine will divide by zero.

param.name: sx
param.pre: SX is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (1+(N-1)*abs(INCX)) The n-element vector x.
The increment between successive values of the vector SX. > 0: SX(1) = X(1) and SX(1+(i-1)*INCX) = x(i), 1< i<= n

para.pre: This is done without overflow or underflow as long as the final result x/a does not overflow or underflow.

remarks.para: Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Estimates the 1-norm of a square, complex matrix A.

param.name: n
param.pre: The order of the matrix. N >= 1.

param.name: v
param.pre: V is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (N) On the final return, V = A*W, where EST = norm(V)/norm(W) (W is not returned).

param.name: x
param.pre: X is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (N) On an intermediate return, X should be overwritten by A * X, if KASE=1, AH * X, if KASE=2, where AH is the conjugate transpose of A, and ZLACN2 must be re-called with all the other parameters unchanged.

param.name: est
param.pre: On entry with KASE = 1 or 2 and ISAVE(1) = 3, EST should be unchanged from the previous call to ZLACN2. On exit, EST is an estimate (a lower bound) for norm(A).

param.name: kase
param.pre: On the initial call to ZLACN2, KASE should be 0. On an intermediate return, KASE will be 1 or 2, indicating whether X should be overwritten by A * X or AH * X. On the final return from ZLACN2, KASE will again be 0.

param.name: isave
param.pre: Dimension (3) ISAVE is used to save variables between calls to ZLACN2

para.pre: Reverse communication is used for evaluating matrix-vector products.

Originally named CONEST, dated March 16, 1988. Last modified: April, 1999 This is a thread safe version of ZLACON, which uses the array ISAVE in place of a SAVE statement, as follows: ZLACON ZLACN2 JUMP ISAVE(1) J ISAVE(2) ITER ISAVE(3)

remarks.para: Nick Higham, University of Manchester
N.J. Higham, "FORTRAN codes for estimating the one-norm of a real or complex matrix, with applications to condition estimation", ACM Trans. Math. Soft., vol. 14, no. 4, pp. 381-396, December 1988.
Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: := X / Y, where X and Y are complex.

param.name: y
param.pre: The complex scalars X and Y.

para.pre: The computation of X / Y will not overflow on an intermediary step unless the results overflows.

remarks.para: Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Solves one of the triangular systems A * x = s*b, AT * x = s*b, or AH * x = s*b, with scaling to prevent overflow, where A is an upper or lower triangular band matrix.

param.name: uplo
param.pre: Specifies whether the matrix A is upper or lower triangular. = 'U': Upper triangular = 'L': Lower triangular

param.name: trans
param.pre: Specifies the operation applied to A. = 'N': Solve A * x = s*b (No transpose) = 'T': Solve AT * x = s*b (Transpose) = 'C': Solve AH * x = s*b (Conjugate transpose)

param.name: diag
param.pre: Specifies whether or not the matrix A is unit triangular. = 'N': Non-unit triangular = 'U': Unit triangular

param.name: normin
param.pre: Specifies whether CNORM has been set or not. = 'Y': CNORM contains the column norms on entry = 'N': CNORM is not set on entry. On exit, the norms will be computed and stored in CNORM.

param.name: n
param.pre: The order of the matrix A. N >= 0.

param.name: kd
param.pre: The number of subdiagonals or superdiagonals in the triangular matrix A. KD >= 0.

param.name: ab
param.pre: AB is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (LDAB,N) The upper or lower triangular band matrix A, stored in the first KD+1 rows of the array. The j-th column of A is stored in the j-th column of the array AB as follows: if UPLO = 'U', AB(kd+1+i-j,j) = A(i,j) for max(1,j-kd)<=i<=j; if UPLO = 'L', AB(1+i-j,j) = A(i,j) for j<=i<=min(n,j+kd).
The leading dimension of the array AB. LDAB >= KD+1.

param.name: x
param.pre: X is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (N) On entry, the right hand side b of the triangular system. On exit, X is overwritten by the solution vector x.

param.name: scale
param.pre: The scaling factor s for the triangular system A * x = s*b, AT * x = s*b, or AH * x = s*b. If SCALE = 0, the matrix A is singular or badly scaled, and the vector x is an exact or approximate solution to A*x = 0.

param.name: cnorm
param.pre: Dimension (N) If NORMIN = 'Y', CNORM is an input argument and CNORM(j) contains the norm of the off-diagonal part of the j-th column of A. If TRANS = 'N', CNORM(j) must be greater than or equal to the infinity-norm, and if TRANS = 'T' or 'C', CNORM(j) must be greater than or equal to the 1-norm. If NORMIN = 'N', CNORM is an output argument and CNORM(j) returns the 1-norm of the offdiagonal part of the j-th column of A.

param.name: info
param.pre: = 0: successful exit < 0: if INFO = -k, the k-th argument had an illegal value

para.pre: Here AT denotes the transpose of A, x and b are n-element vectors, and s is a scaling factor, usually less than or equal to 1, chosen so that the components of x will be less than the overflow threshold. If the unscaled problem will not cause overflow, the Level 2 BLAS routine ZTBSV is called. If the matrix A is singular (A(j,j) = 0 for some j), then s is set to 0 and a non-trivial solution to A*x = 0 is returned.

A rough bound on x is computed; if that is less than overflow, ZTBSV is called, otherwise, specific code is used which checks for possible overflow or divide-by-zero at every operation. A columnwise scheme is used for solving A*x = b. The basic algorithm if A is lower triangular is x[1:n] := b[1:n] for j = 1, ..., n x(j) := x(j) / A(j,j) x[j+1:n] := x[j+1:n] - x(j) * A[j+1:n,j] end Define bounds on the components of x after j iterations of the loop: M(j) = bound on x[1:j] G(j) = bound on x[j+1:n] Initially, let M(0) = 0 and G(0) = max{x(i), i=1,...,n}. Then for iteration j+1 we have M(j+1) <= G(j) / | A(j+1,j+1) | G(j+1) <= G(j) + M(j+1) * | A[j+2:n,j+1] | <= G(j) ( 1 + CNORM(j+1) / | A(j+1,j+1) | ) where CNORM(j+1) is greater than or equal to the infinity-norm of column j+1 of A, not counting the diagonal. Hence G(j) <= G(0) product ( 1 + CNORM(i) / | A(i,i) | ) 1<=i<=j and |x(j)| <= ( G(0) / |A(j,j)| ) product ( 1 + CNORM(i) / |A(i,i)| ) 1<=i< j Since |x(j)| <= M(j), we use the Level 2 BLAS routine ZTBSV if the reciprocal of the largest M(j), j=1,..,n, is larger than max(underflow, 1/overflow). The bound on x(j) is also used to determine when a step in the columnwise method can be performed without fear of overflow. If the computed bound is greater than a large constant, x is scaled to prevent overflow, but if the bound overflows, x is set to 0, x(j) to 1, and scale to 0, and a non-trivial solution to A*x = 0 is found. Similarly, a row-wise scheme is used to solve AT *x = b or AH *x = b. The basic algorithm for A upper triangular is for j = 1, ..., n x(j) := ( b(j) - A[1:j-1,j]' * x[1:j-1] ) / A(j,j) end We simultaneously compute two bounds G(j) = bound on ( b(i) - A[1:i-1,i]' * x[1:i-1] ), 1<=i<=j M(j) = bound on x(i), 1<=i<=j The initial values are G(0) = 0, M(0) = max{b(i), i=1,..,n}, and we add the constraint G(j) >= G(j-1) and M(j) >= M(j-1) for j >= 1. Then the bound on x(j) is M(j) <= M(j-1) * ( 1 + CNORM(j) ) / | A(j,j) | <= M(0) * product ( ( 1 + CNORM(i) ) / |A(i,i)| ) 1<=i<=j and we can safely call ZTBSV if 1/M(n) and 1/G(n) are both greater than max(underflow, 1/overflow).

remarks.para: Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Performs a series of row interchanges on the matrix A.

param.name: n
param.pre: The number of columns of the matrix A.

param.name: a
param.pre: A is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (LDA,N) On entry, the matrix of column dimension N to which the row interchanges will be applied. On exit, the permuted matrix.
The leading dimension of the array A.

param.name: k1
param.pre: The first element of IPIV for which a row interchange will be done.

param.name: k2
param.pre: The last element of IPIV for which a row interchange will be done.

param.name: ipiv
param.pre: Dimension (K2*abs(INCX)) The vector of pivot indices. Only the elements in positions K1 through K2 of IPIV are accessed. IPIV(K) = L implies rows K and L are to be interchanged.

param.name: incx
param.pre: The increment between successive values of IPIV. If IPIV is negative, the pivots are applied in reverse order.

para.pre: One row interchange is initiated for each of rows K1 through K2 of A.
Modified by R. C. Whaley, Computer Science Dept., Univ. of Tenn., Knoxville, USA

remarks.para: Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Conjugates a complex vector of length N.

param.name: n
param.pre: The length of the vector X. N >= 0.

param.name: x
param.pre: X is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (1+(N-1)*abs(INCX)) On entry, the vector of length N to be conjugated. On exit, X is overwritten with conjg(X).
The spacing between successive elements of X.

remarks.para: Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Solves one of the triangular systems A * x = s*b, AT * x = s*b, or AH * x = s*b, with scaling to prevent overflow.

param.name: uplo
param.pre: Specifies whether the matrix A is upper or lower triangular. = 'U': Upper triangular = 'L': Lower triangular

param.name: trans
param.pre: Specifies the operation applied to A. = 'N': Solve A * x = s*b (No transpose) = 'T': Solve AT * x = s*b (Transpose) = 'C': Solve AH * x = s*b (Conjugate transpose)

param.name: diag
param.pre: Specifies whether or not the matrix A is unit triangular. = 'N': Non-unit triangular = 'U': Unit triangular

param.name: normin
param.pre: Specifies whether CNORM has been set or not. = 'Y': CNORM contains the column norms on entry = 'N': CNORM is not set on entry. On exit, the norms will be computed and stored in CNORM.

param.name: n
param.pre: The order of the matrix A. N >= 0.

param.name: a
param.pre: A is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (LDA,N) The triangular matrix A. If UPLO = 'U', the leading n by n upper triangular part of the array A contains the upper triangular matrix, and the strictly lower triangular part of A is not referenced. If UPLO = 'L', the leading n by n lower triangular part of the array A contains the lower triangular matrix, and the strictly upper triangular part of A is not referenced. If DIAG = 'U', the diagonal elements of A are also not referenced and are assumed to be 1.
The leading dimension of the array A. LDA >= max (1,N).

param.name: x
param.pre: X is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (N) On entry, the right hand side b of the triangular system. On exit, X is overwritten by the solution vector x.

param.name: scale
param.pre: The scaling factor s for the triangular system A * x = s*b, AT * x = s*b, or AH * x = s*b. If SCALE = 0, the matrix A is singular or badly scaled, and the vector x is an exact or approximate solution to A*x = 0.

param.name: cnorm
param.pre: Dimension (N) If NORMIN = 'Y', CNORM is an input argument and CNORM(j) contains the norm of the off-diagonal part of the j-th column of A. If TRANS = 'N', CNORM(j) must be greater than or equal to the infinity-norm, and if TRANS = 'T' or 'C', CNORM(j) must be greater than or equal to the 1-norm. If NORMIN = 'N', CNORM is an output argument and CNORM(j) returns the 1-norm of the offdiagonal part of the j-th column of A.

param.name: info
param.pre: = 0: successful exit < 0: if INFO = -k, the k-th argument had an illegal value

para.pre: Here A is an upper or lower triangular matrix, AT denotes the transpose of A, AH denotes the conjugate transpose of A, x and b are n-element vectors, and s is a scaling factor, usually less than or equal to 1, chosen so that the components of x will be less than the overflow threshold. If the unscaled problem will not cause overflow, the Level 2 BLAS routine ZTRSV is called. If the matrix A is singular (A(j,j) = 0 for some j), then s is set to 0 and a non-trivial solution to A*x = 0 is returned.

A rough bound on x is computed; if that is less than overflow, ZTRSV is called, otherwise, specific code is used which checks for possible overflow or divide-by-zero at every operation. A columnwise scheme is used for solving A*x = b. The basic algorithm if A is lower triangular is x[1:n] := b[1:n] for j = 1, ..., n x(j) := x(j) / A(j,j) x[j+1:n] := x[j+1:n] - x(j) * A[j+1:n,j] end Define bounds on the components of x after j iterations of the loop: M(j) = bound on x[1:j] G(j) = bound on x[j+1:n] Initially, let M(0) = 0 and G(0) = max{x(i), i=1,...,n}. Then for iteration j+1 we have M(j+1) <= G(j) / | A(j+1,j+1) | G(j+1) <= G(j) + M(j+1) * | A[j+2:n,j+1] | <= G(j) ( 1 + CNORM(j+1) / | A(j+1,j+1) | ) where CNORM(j+1) is greater than or equal to the infinity-norm of column j+1 of A, not counting the diagonal. Hence G(j) <= G(0) product ( 1 + CNORM(i) / | A(i,i) | ) 1<=i<=j and |x(j)| <= ( G(0) / |A(j,j)| ) product ( 1 + CNORM(i) / |A(i,i)| ) 1<=i< j Since |x(j)| <= M(j), we use the Level 2 BLAS routine ZTRSV if the reciprocal of the largest M(j), j=1,..,n, is larger than max(underflow, 1/overflow). The bound on x(j) is also used to determine when a step in the columnwise method can be performed without fear of overflow. If the computed bound is greater than a large constant, x is scaled to prevent overflow, but if the bound overflows, x is set to 0, x(j) to 1, and scale to 0, and a non-trivial solution to A*x = 0 is found. Similarly, a row-wise scheme is used to solve AT *x = b or AH *x = b. The basic algorithm for A upper triangular is for j = 1, ..., n x(j) := ( b(j) - A[1:j-1,j]' * x[1:j-1] ) / A(j,j) end We simultaneously compute two bounds G(j) = bound on ( b(i) - A[1:i-1,i]' * x[1:i-1] ), 1<=i<=j M(j) = bound on x(i), 1<=i<=j The initial values are G(0) = 0, M(0) = max{b(i), i=1,..,n}, and we add the constraint G(j) >= G(j-1) and M(j) >= M(j-1) for j >= 1. Then the bound on x(j) is M(j) <= M(j-1) * ( 1 + CNORM(j) ) / | A(j,j) | <= M(0) * product ( ( 1 + CNORM(i) ) / |A(i,i)| ) 1<=i<=j and we can safely call ZTRSV if 1/M(n) and 1/G(n) are both greater than max(underflow, 1/overflow).

remarks.para: Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Applies a complex elementary reflector H to a complex M-by-N matrix C, from either the left or the right.

param.name: side
param.pre: = 'L': form H * C = 'R': form C * H

param.name: m
param.pre: The number of rows of the matrix C.

param.name: n
param.pre: The number of columns of the matrix C.

param.name: v
param.pre: V is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (1 + (M-1)*abs(INCV)) if SIDE = 'L' or (1 + (N-1)*abs(INCV)) if SIDE = 'R' The vector v in the representation of H. V is not used if TAU = 0.
The increment between elements of v. INCV <> 0.

param.name: tau
param.pre: The value tau in the representation of H.

param.name: c
param.pre: C is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (LDC,N) On entry, the M-by-N matrix C. On exit, C is overwritten by the matrix H * C if SIDE = 'L', or C * H if SIDE = 'R'.
The leading dimension of the array C. LDC >= max(1,M).

param.name: work
param.pre: WORK is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (N) if SIDE = 'L' or (M) if SIDE = 'R'

para.pre: H is represented in the form H = I - tau * v * v**H where tau is a complex scalar and v is a complex vector. If tau = 0, then H is taken to be the unit matrix. To apply HH, supply conjg(tau) instead tau.

remarks.para: Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Generates a complex elementary reflector H of order n, such that HH * ( alpha ) = ( beta ), HH * H = I.

param.name: n
param.pre: The order of the elementary reflector.

param.name: alpha
param.pre: On entry, the value alpha. On exit, it is overwritten with the value beta.

param.name: x
param.pre: X is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (1+(N-2)*abs(INCX)) On entry, the vector x. On exit, it is overwritten with the vector v.
The increment between elements of X. INCX > 0.

param.name: tau
param.pre: The value tau.

para.pre: ( x ) ( 0 ) where alpha and beta are scalars, with beta real, and x is an (n-1)-element complex vector. H is represented in the form H = I - tau * ( 1 ) * ( 1 v**H ) , ( v ) where tau is a complex scalar and v is a complex (n-1)-element vector. Note that H is not hermitian. If the elements of x are all zero and alpha is real, then tau = 0 and H is taken to be the unit matrix. Otherwise 1 <= real(tau) <= 2 and abs(tau-1) <= 1 .

remarks.para: Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Copies all or part of a two-dimensional matrix A to another matrix B.

param.name: uplo
param.pre: Specifies the part of the matrix A to be copied to B. = 'U': Upper triangular part = 'L': Lower triangular part Otherwise: All of the matrix A

param.name: m
param.pre: The number of rows of the matrix A. M >= 0.

param.name: n
param.pre: The number of columns of the matrix A. N >= 0.

param.name: a
param.pre: A is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (LDA,N) The m by n matrix A. If UPLO = 'U', only the upper trapezium is accessed; if UPLO = 'L', only the lower trapezium is accessed.
The leading dimension of the array A. LDA >= max(1,M).

param.name: b
param.pre: B is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (LDB,N) On exit, B = A in the locations specified by UPLO.
The leading dimension of the array B. LDB >= max(1,M).

remarks.para: Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Reduces the first NB columns of A complex general n-BY-(n-k+1) matrix A so that elements below the k-th sub-diagonal are zero.

param.name: n
param.pre: The order of the matrix A.

param.name: k
param.pre: The offset for the reduction. Elements below the k-th sub-diagonal in the first NB columns are reduced to zero. K < N.

param.name: nb
param.pre: The number of columns to be reduced.

param.name: a
param.pre: A is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (LDA,N-K+1) On entry, the n-by-(n-k+1) general matrix A. On exit, the elements on and above the k-th sub-diagonal in the first NB columns are overwritten with the corresponding elements of the reduced matrix; the elements below the k-th sub-diagonal, with the array TAU, represent the matrix Q as a product of elementary reflectors. The other columns of A are unchanged. See Further Details.
The leading dimension of the array A. LDA >= max(1,N).

param.name: tau
param.pre: TAU is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (NB) The scalar factors of the elementary reflectors. See Further Details.

param.name: t
param.pre: T is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (LDT,NB) The upper triangular matrix T.
The leading dimension of the array T. LDT >= NB.

param.name: y
param.pre: Y is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (LDY,NB) The n-by-nb matrix Y.
The leading dimension of the array Y. LDY >= N.

para.pre: The reduction is performed by an unitary similarity transformation QH * A * Q. The routine returns the matrices V and T which determine Q as a block reflector I - V*T*VH, and also the matrix Y = A * V * T. This is an auxiliary routine called by ZGEHRD.

The matrix Q is represented as a product of nb elementary reflectors Q = H(1) H(2) . . . H(nb). Each H(i) has the form H(i) = I - tau * v * v**H where tau is a complex scalar, and v is a complex vector with v(1:i+k-1) = 0, v(i+k) = 1; v(i+k+1:n) is stored on exit in A(i+k+1:n,i), and tau in TAU(i). The elements of the vectors v together form the (n-k+1)-by-nb matrix V which is needed, with T and Y, to apply the transformation to the unreduced part of the matrix, using an update of the form: A := (I - V*T*VH) * (A - Y*VH). The contents of A on exit are illustrated by the following example with n = 7, k = 3 and nb = 2: ( a a a a a ) ( a a a a a ) ( a a a a a ) ( h h a a a ) ( v1 h a a a ) ( v1 v2 a a a ) ( v1 v2 a a a ) where a denotes an element of the original matrix A, h denotes a modified element of the upper Hessenberg matrix H, and vi denotes an element of the vector defining H(i). This subroutine is a slight modification of LAPACK-3.0's DLAHRD incorporating improvements proposed by Quintana-Orti and Van de Gejin. Note that the entries of A(1:K,2:NB) differ from those returned by the original LAPACK-3.0's DLAHRD routine. (This subroutine is not backward compatible with LAPACK-3.0's DLAHRD.)

remarks.para: Gregorio Quintana-Orti and Robert van de Geijn, "Improving the performance of reduction to Hessenberg form," ACM Transactions on Mathematical Software, 32(2):180-194, June 2006.
Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Applies a complex block reflector H or its transpose HH to a complex M-by-N matrix C, from either the left or the right.

param.name: side
param.pre: = 'L': apply H or HH from the Left = 'R': apply H or HH from the Right

param.name: trans
param.pre: = 'N': apply H (No transpose) = 'C': apply HH (Conjugate transpose)

param.name: direct
param.pre: Indicates how H is formed from a product of elementary reflectors = 'F': H = H(1) H(2) . . . H(k) (Forward) = 'B': H = H(k) . . . H(2) H(1) (Backward)

param.name: storev
param.pre: Indicates how the vectors which define the elementary reflectors are stored: = 'C': Columnwise = 'R': Rowwise

param.name: m
param.pre: The number of rows of the matrix C.

param.name: n
param.pre: The number of columns of the matrix C.

param.name: k
param.pre: The order of the matrix T (= the number of elementary reflectors whose product defines the block reflector).

param.name: v
param.pre: V is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (LDV,K) if STOREV = 'C' (LDV,M) if STOREV = 'R' and SIDE = 'L' (LDV,N) if STOREV = 'R' and SIDE = 'R' See Further Details.

param.name: t
param.pre: T is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (LDT,K) The triangular K-by-K matrix T in the representation of the block reflector.
The leading dimension of the array T. LDT >= K.

param.name: c
param.pre: C is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (LDC,N) On entry, the M-by-N matrix C. On exit, C is overwritten by H*C or HH*C or C*H or C*HH.
The leading dimension of the array C. LDC >= max(1,M).

param.name: work
param.pre: WORK is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (LDWORK,K)

para.pre: The shape of the matrix V and the storage of the vectors which define the H(i) is best illustrated by the following example with n = 5 and k = 3. The elements equal to 1 are not stored; the corresponding array elements are modified but restored on exit. The rest of the array is not used. DIRECT = 'F' and STOREV = 'C': DIRECT = 'F' and STOREV = 'R': V = ( 1 ) V = ( 1 v1 v1 v1 v1 ) ( v1 1 ) ( 1 v2 v2 v2 ) ( v1 v2 1 ) ( 1 v3 v3 ) ( v1 v2 v3 ) ( v1 v2 v3 ) DIRECT = 'B' and STOREV = 'C': DIRECT = 'B' and STOREV = 'R': V = ( v1 v2 v3 ) V = ( v1 v1 1 ) ( v1 v2 v3 ) ( v2 v2 v2 1 ) ( 1 v2 v3 ) ( v3 v3 v3 v3 1 ) ( 1 v3 ) ( 1 )

remarks.para: Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Is an auxiliary routine called by CHSEQR to update the eigenvalues and Schur decomposition already computed by CHSEQR, by dealing with the Hessenberg sub-matrix in rows and columns ILO to IHI.

param.name: wantt
param.pre: = .TRUE. : the full Schur form T is required; = .FALSE.: only eigenvalues are required.

param.name: wantz
param.pre: = .TRUE. : the matrix of Schur vectors Z is required; = .FALSE.: Schur vectors are not required.

param.name: n
param.pre: The order of the matrix H. N >= 0.

param.name: ihi
param.pre: It is assumed that H is already upper triangular in rows and columns IHI+1:N, and that H(ILO,ILO-1) = 0 (unless ILO = 1). ZLAHQR works primarily with the Hessenberg sub-matrix in rows and columns ILO to IHI, but applies transformations to all of H if WANTT is .TRUE.. 1 <= ILO <= max(1,IHI); IHI <= N.

param.name: h
param.pre: H is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (LDH,N) On entry, the upper Hessenberg matrix H. On exit, if INFO is zero and if WANTT is .TRUE., then H is upper triangular in rows and columns ILO:IHI. If INFO is zero and if WANTT is .FALSE., then the contents of H are unspecified on exit. The output state of H in case INF is positive is below under the description of INFO.
The leading dimension of the array H. LDH >= max(1,N).

param.name: w
param.pre: W is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (N) The computed eigenvalues ILO to IHI are stored in the corresponding elements of W. If WANTT is .TRUE., the eigenvalues are stored in the same order as on the diagonal of the Schur form returned in H, with W(i) = H(i,i).

param.name: ihiz
param.pre: Specify the rows of Z to which transformations must be applied if WANTZ is .TRUE.. 1 <= ILOZ <= ILO; IHI <= IHIZ <= N.

param.name: z
param.pre: Z is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (LDZ,N) If WANTZ is .TRUE., on entry Z must contain the current matrix Z of transformations accumulated by CHSEQR, and on exit Z has been updated; transformations are applied only to the sub-matrix Z(ILOZ:IHIZ,ILO:IHI). If WANTZ is .FALSE., Z is not referenced.
The leading dimension of the array Z. LDZ >= max(1,N).

param.name: info
param.pre: = 0: successful exit > 0: if INFO = i, ZLAHQR failed to compute all the eigenvalues ILO to IHI in a total of 30 iterations per eigenvalue; elements i+1:ihi of W contain those eigenvalues which have been successfully computed. If INFO > 0 and WANTT is .FALSE., then on exit, the remaining unconverged eigenvalues are the eigenvalues of the upper Hessenberg matrix rows and columns ILO thorugh INFO of the final, output value of H. If INFO > 0 and WANTT is .TRUE., then on exit (*) (initial value of H)*U = U*(final value of H) where U is an orthognal matrix. The final value of H is upper Hessenberg and triangular in rows and columns INFO+1 through IHI. If INFO > 0 and WANTZ is .TRUE., then on exit (final value of Z) = (initial value of Z)*U where U is the orthogonal matrix in (*) (regardless of the value of WANTT.)

para.pre: 02-96 Based on modifications by David Day, Sandia National Laboratory, USA 12-04 Further modifications by Ralph Byers, University of Kansas, USA This is a modified version of ZLAHQR from LAPACK version 3.0. It is (1) more robust against overflow and underflow and (2) adopts the more conservative Ahues & Tisseur stopping criterion (LAWN 122, 1997).

remarks.para: Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Initializes a 2-D array A to BETA on the diagonal and ALPHA on the offdiagonals.

param.name: uplo
param.pre: Specifies the part of the matrix A to be set. = 'U': Upper triangular part is set. The lower triangle is unchanged. = 'L': Lower triangular part is set. The upper triangle is unchanged. Otherwise: All of the matrix A is set.

param.name: m
param.pre: On entry, M specifies the number of rows of A.

param.name: n
param.pre: On entry, N specifies the number of columns of A.

param.name: alpha
param.pre: All the offdiagonal array elements are set to ALPHA.

param.name: beta
param.pre: All the diagonal array elements are set to BETA.

param.name: a
param.pre: A is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (LDA,N) On entry, the m by n matrix A. On exit, A(i,j) = ALPHA, 1 <= i <= m, 1 <= j <= n, i.ne.j; A(i,i) = BETA , 1 <= i <= min(m,n)
The leading dimension of the array A. LDA >= max(1,M).

remarks.para: Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Generates a plane rotation so that [ CS SN ] [ F ] [ R ] [ __ ] .

param.name: f
param.pre: The first component of vector to be rotated.

param.name: g
param.pre: The second component of vector to be rotated.

param.name: cs
param.pre: The cosine of the rotation.

param.name: sn
param.pre: The sine of the rotation.

param.name: r
param.pre: The nonzero component of the rotated vector.

para.pre: [ ] = [ ] where CS**2 + |SN|**2 = 1. [ -SN CS ] [ G ] [ 0 ] This is a faster version of the BLAS1 routine ZROTG, except for the following differences: F and G are unchanged on return. If G=0, then CS=1 and SN=0. If F=0, then CS=0 and SN is chosen so that R is real.
3-5-96 - Modified with a new algorithm by W. Kahan and J. Demmel This version has a few statements commented out for thread safety (machine parameters are computed on each entry). 10 feb 03, SJH.

remarks.para: Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Applies a plane rotation, where the cos (C) is real and the sin (S) is complex, and the vectors CX and CY are complex.

param.name: n
param.pre: The number of elements in the vectors CX and CY.

param.name: cx
param.pre: CX is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (N) On input, the vector X. On return, CX is overwritten with C*X + S*Y.
The increment between successive values of CY. INCX <> 0.

param.name: cy
param.pre: CY is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (N) On input, the vector Y. On return, CY is overwritten with -CONJG(S)*X + C*Y.
The increment between successive values of CY. INCX <> 0.

param.name: s
param.pre: C and S define a rotation [ C S ] [ -conjg(S) C ] where C*C + S*CONJG(S) = 1.0.

remarks.para: Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Forms the triangular factor T of a complex block reflector H of order n, which is defined as a product of k elementary reflectors.

param.name: direct
param.pre: Specifies the order in which the elementary reflectors are multiplied to form the block reflector: = 'F': H = H(1) H(2) . . . H(k) (Forward) = 'B': H = H(k) . . . H(2) H(1) (Backward)

param.name: storev
param.pre: Specifies how the vectors which define the elementary reflectors are stored (see also Further Details): = 'C': columnwise = 'R': rowwise

param.name: n
param.pre: The order of the block reflector H. N >= 0.

param.name: k
param.pre: The order of the triangular factor T (= the number of elementary reflectors). K >= 1.

param.name: v
param.pre: V is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (LDV,K) if STOREV = 'C' (LDV,N) if STOREV = 'R' The matrix V. See further details.
The leading dimension of the array V. If STOREV = 'C', LDV >= max(1,N); if STOREV = 'R', LDV >= K.

param.name: tau
param.pre: TAU is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (K) TAU(i) must contain the scalar factor of the elementary reflector H(i).

param.name: t
param.pre: T is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (LDT,K) The k by k triangular factor T of the block reflector. If DIRECT = 'F', T is upper triangular; if DIRECT = 'B', T is lower triangular. The rest of the array is not used.
The leading dimension of the array T. LDT >= K.

para.pre: If DIRECT = 'F', H = H(1) H(2) . . . H(k) and T is upper triangular; If DIRECT = 'B', H = H(k) . . . H(2) H(1) and T is lower triangular. If STOREV = 'C', the vector which defines the elementary reflector H(i) is stored in the i-th column of the array V, and H = I - V * T * VH If STOREV = 'R', the vector which defines the elementary reflector H(i) is stored in the i-th row of the array V, and H = I - VH * T * V

The shape of the matrix V and the storage of the vectors which define the H(i) is best illustrated by the following example with n = 5 and k = 3. The elements equal to 1 are not stored. DIRECT = 'F' and STOREV = 'C': DIRECT = 'F' and STOREV = 'R': V = ( 1 ) V = ( 1 v1 v1 v1 v1 ) ( v1 1 ) ( 1 v2 v2 v2 ) ( v1 v2 1 ) ( 1 v3 v3 ) ( v1 v2 v3 ) ( v1 v2 v3 ) DIRECT = 'B' and STOREV = 'C': DIRECT = 'B' and STOREV = 'R': V = ( v1 v2 v3 ) V = ( v1 v1 1 ) ( v1 v2 v3 ) ( v2 v2 v2 1 ) ( 1 v2 v3 ) ( v3 v3 v3 v3 1 ) ( 1 v3 ) ( 1 )

remarks.para: Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Is identical to ZLAQR3 except that it avoids recursion by calling ZLAHQR instead of ZLAQR4.

param.name: wantt
param.pre: If .TRUE., then the Hessenberg matrix H is fully updated so that the triangular Schur factor may be computed (in cooperation with the calling subroutine). If .FALSE., then only enough of H is updated to preserve the eigenvalues.

param.name: wantz
param.pre: If .TRUE., then the unitary matrix Z is updated so so that the unitary Schur factor may be computed (in cooperation with the calling subroutine). If .FALSE., then Z is not referenced.

param.name: n
param.pre: The order of the matrix H and (if WANTZ is .TRUE.) the order of the unitary matrix Z.

param.name: ktop
param.pre: It is assumed that either KTOP = 1 or H(KTOP,KTOP-1)=0. KBOT and KTOP together determine an isolated block along the diagonal of the Hessenberg matrix.

param.name: kbot
param.pre: It is assumed without a check that either KBOT = N or H(KBOT+1,KBOT)=0. KBOT and KTOP together determine an isolated block along the diagonal of the Hessenberg matrix.

param.name: nw
param.pre: Deflation window size. 1 <= NW <= (KBOT-KTOP+1).

param.name: h
param.pre: H is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (LDH,N) On input the initial N-by-N section of H stores the Hessenberg matrix undergoing aggressive early deflation. On return H has been transformed by a unitary similarity transformation, perturbed, and the returned to Hessenberg form that (it is to be hoped) has some zero sub-diagonal entries.
LDH is integer Leading dimension of H just as declared in the calling subroutine. N <= LDH

param.name: ihiz
param.pre: Specify the rows of Z to which transformations must be applied if WANTZ is .TRUE.. 1 <= ILOZ <= IHIZ <= N.

param.name: z
param.pre: Z is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (LDZ,N) IF WANTZ is .TRUE., then On return, the unitary similarity transformation mentioned above has been accumulated into Z(ILOZ:IHIZ,ILO:IHI) from the right. If WANTZ is .FALSE., then Z is unreferenced.
LDZ is integer The leading dimension of Z just as declared in the calling subroutine. 1 <= LDZ.

param.name: ns
param.pre: NS is integer The number of unconverged (ie approximate) eigenvalues returned in SR and SI that may be used as shifts by the calling subroutine.

param.name: nd
param.pre: ND is integer The number of converged eigenvalues uncovered by this subroutine.

param.name: sh
param.pre: SH is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension KBOT On return, approximate eigenvalues that may be used for shifts are stored in SH(KBOT-ND-NS+1) through SR(KBOT-ND). Converged eigenvalues are stored in SH(KBOT-ND+1) through SH(KBOT).

param.name: v
param.pre: V is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (LDV,NW) An NW-by-NW work array.
LDV is integer scalar The leading dimension of V just as declared in the calling subroutine. NW <= LDV

param.name: nh
param.pre: NH is integer scalar The number of columns of T. NH >= NW.

param.name: t
param.pre: T is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (LDT,NW)
LDT is integer The leading dimension of T just as declared in the calling subroutine. NW <= LDT

param.name: nv
param.pre: NV is integer The number of rows of work array WV available for workspace. NV >= NW.

param.name: wv
param.pre: WV is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (LDWV,NW)
LDWV is integer The leading dimension of W just as declared in the calling subroutine. NW <= LDV

param.name: work
param.pre: WORK is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension LWORK. On exit, WORK(1) is set to an estimate of the optimal value of LWORK for the given values of N, NW, KTOP and KBOT.

param.name: lwork
param.pre: LWORK is integer The dimension of the work array WORK. LWORK = 2*NW suffices, but greater efficiency may result from larger values of LWORK. If LWORK = -1, then a workspace query is assumed; ZLAQR2 only estimates the optimal workspace size for the given values of N, NW, KTOP and KBOT. The estimate is returned in WORK(1). No error message related to LWORK is issued by XERBLA. Neither H nor Z are accessed.

para.pre: Aggressive early deflation: ZLAQR2 accepts as input an upper Hessenberg matrix H and performs an unitary similarity transformation designed to detect and deflate fully converged eigenvalues from a trailing principal sub-matrix. On return H has been over- written by a new Hessenberg matrix that is a perturbation of an unitary similarity transformation of H. It is to be hoped that the final version of H has many zero sub-diagonal entries.

remarks.para: Karen Braman and Ralph Byers, Department of Mathematics, University of Kansas, USA
Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: A 2-by-2 or 3-by-3 matrix H, ZLAQR1 sets v to a scalar multiple of the first column of the product (*) K = (H - s1*I)*(H - s2*I) scaling to avoid overflows and most underflows.

param.name: n
param.pre: N is integer Order of the matrix H. N must be either 2 or 3.

param.name: h
param.pre: H is COMPLEX*16 array of dimension (LDH,N) The 2-by-2 or 3-by-3 matrix H in (*).
LDH is integer The leading dimension of H as declared in the calling procedure. LDH >= N

param.name: s1
param.pre: S1 is COMPLEX*16

param.name: s2
param.pre: S2 is COMPLEX*16 S1 and S2 are the shifts defining K in (*) above.

param.name: v
param.pre: V is COMPLEX*16 array of dimension N A scalar multiple of the first column of the matrix K in (*).

para.pre: This is useful for starting T implicit shift bulges in the QR algorithm.

remarks.para: Karen Braman and Ralph Byers, Department of Mathematics, University of Kansas, USA
Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Called by ZLAQR0, performs a single small-bulge multi-shift QR sweep.

param.name: wantt
param.pre: WANTT is logical scalar WANTT = .true. if the triangular Schur factor is being computed. WANTT is set to .false. otherwise.

param.name: wantz
param.pre: WANTZ is logical scalar WANTZ = .true. if the unitary Schur factor is being computed. WANTZ is set to .false. otherwise.

param.name: kacc22
param.pre: KACC22 is integer with value 0, 1, or 2. Specifies the computation mode of far-from-diagonal orthogonal updates. = 0: ZLAQR5 does not accumulate reflections and does not use matrix-matrix multiply to update far-from-diagonal matrix entries. = 1: ZLAQR5 accumulates reflections and uses matrix-matrix multiply to update the far-from-diagonal matrix entries. = 2: ZLAQR5 accumulates reflections, uses matrix-matrix multiply to update the far-from-diagonal matrix entries, and takes advantage of 2-by-2 block structure during matrix multiplies.

param.name: n
param.pre: N is integer scalar N is the order of the Hessenberg matrix H upon which this subroutine operates.

param.name: ktop
param.pre: KTOP is integer scalar

param.name: kbot
param.pre: KBOT is integer scalar These are the first and last rows and columns of an isolated diagonal block upon which the QR sweep is to be applied. It is assumed without a check that either KTOP = 1 or H(KTOP,KTOP-1) = 0 and either KBOT = N or H(KBOT+1,KBOT) = 0.

param.name: nshfts
param.pre: NSHFTS is integer scalar NSHFTS gives the number of simultaneous shifts. NSHFTS must be positive and even.

param.name: s
param.pre: S is COMPLEX*16 array of size (NSHFTS) S contains the shifts of origin that define the multi- shift QR sweep. On return S may be reordered.

param.name: h
param.pre: H is COMPLEX*16 array of size (LDH,N) On input H contains a Hessenberg matrix. On return a multi-shift QR sweep with shifts SR(J)+i*SI(J) is applied to the isolated diagonal block in rows and columns KTOP through KBOT.
LDH is integer scalar LDH is the leading dimension of H just as declared in the calling procedure. LDH >= MAX(1,N).

param.name: ihiz
param.pre: Specify the rows of Z to which transformations must be applied if WANTZ is .TRUE.. 1 <= ILOZ <= IHIZ <= N

param.name: z
param.pre: Z is COMPLEX*16 array of size (LDZ,IHI) If WANTZ = .TRUE., then the QR Sweep unitary similarity transformation is accumulated into Z(ILOZ:IHIZ,ILO:IHI) from the right. If WANTZ = .FALSE., then Z is unreferenced.
LDZ is integer scalar LDA is the leading dimension of Z just as declared in the calling procedure. LDZ >= N.

param.name: v
param.pre: V is COMPLEX*16 array of size (LDV,NSHFTS/2)
LDV is integer scalar LDV is the leading dimension of V as declared in the calling procedure. LDV >= 3.

param.name: u
param.pre: U is COMPLEX*16 array of size (LDU,3*NSHFTS-3)
LDU is integer scalar LDU is the leading dimension of U just as declared in the in the calling subroutine. LDU >= 3*NSHFTS-3.

param.name: nh
param.pre: NH is integer scalar NH is the number of columns in array WH available for workspace. NH >= 1.

param.name: wh
param.pre: WH is COMPLEX*16 array of size (LDWH,NH)
LDWH is integer scalar Leading dimension of WH just as declared in the calling procedure. LDWH >= 3*NSHFTS-3.

param.name: nv
param.pre: NV is integer scalar NV is the number of rows in WV agailable for workspace. NV >= 1.

param.name: wv
param.pre: WV is COMPLEX*16 array of size (LDWV,3*NSHFTS-3)
LDWV is integer scalar LDWV is the leading dimension of WV as declared in the in the calling subroutine. LDWV >= NV.

remarks.para: Karen Braman and Ralph Byers, Department of Mathematics, University of Kansas, USA
K. Braman, R. Byers and R. Mathias, The Multi-Shift QR Algorithm Part I: Maintaining Well Focused Shifts, and Level 3 Performance, SIAM Journal of Matrix Analysis, volume 23, pages 929--947, 2002.
Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Implements one level of recursion for ZLAQR0.

param.name: wantt
param.pre: = .TRUE. : the full Schur form T is required; = .FALSE.: only eigenvalues are required.

param.name: wantz
param.pre: = .TRUE. : the matrix of Schur vectors Z is required; = .FALSE.: Schur vectors are not required.

param.name: n
param.pre: The order of the matrix H. N >= 0.

param.name: ihi
param.pre: It is assumed that H is already upper triangular in rows and columns 1:ILO-1 and IHI+1:N and, if ILO > 1, H(ILO,ILO-1) is zero. ILO and IHI are normally set by a previous call to ZGEBAL, and then passed to ZGEHRD when the matrix output by ZGEBAL is reduced to Hessenberg form. Otherwise, ILO and IHI should be set to 1 and N, respectively. If N > 0, then 1 <= ILO <= IHI <= N. If N = 0, then ILO = 1 and IHI = 0.

param.name: h
param.pre: H is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (LDH,N) On entry, the upper Hessenberg matrix H. On exit, if INFO = 0 and WANTT is .TRUE., then H contains the upper triangular matrix T from the Schur decomposition (the Schur form). If INFO = 0 and WANT is .FALSE., then the contents of H are unspecified on exit. (The output value of H when INFO > 0 is given under the description of INFO below.) This subroutine may explicitly set H(i,j) = 0 for i > j and j = 1, 2, ... ILO-1 or j = IHI+1, IHI+2, ... N.
The leading dimension of the array H. LDH >= max(1,N).

param.name: w
param.pre: W is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (N) The computed eigenvalues of H(ILO:IHI,ILO:IHI) are stored in W(ILO:IHI). If WANTT is .TRUE., then the eigenvalues are stored in the same order as on the diagonal of the Schur form returned in H, with W(i) = H(i,i).

param.name: ihiz
param.pre: Specify the rows of Z to which transformations must be applied if WANTZ is .TRUE.. 1 <= ILOZ <= ILO; IHI <= IHIZ <= N.

param.name: z
param.pre: Z is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (LDZ,IHI) If WANTZ is .FALSE., then Z is not referenced. If WANTZ is .TRUE., then Z(ILO:IHI,ILOZ:IHIZ) is replaced by Z(ILO:IHI,ILOZ:IHIZ)*U where U is the orthogonal Schur factor of H(ILO:IHI,ILO:IHI). (The output value of Z when INFO > 0 is given under the description of INFO below.)
The leading dimension of the array Z. if WANTZ is .TRUE. then LDZ >= MAX(1,IHIZ). Otherwize, LDZ >= 1.

param.name: work
param.pre: WORK is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension LWORK On exit, if LWORK = -1, WORK(1) returns an estimate of the optimal value for LWORK.

param.name: lwork
param.pre: The dimension of the array WORK. LWORK >= max(1,N) is sufficient, but LWORK typically as large as 6*N may be required for optimal performance. A workspace query to determine the optimal workspace size is recommended. If LWORK = -1, then ZLAQR4 does a workspace query. In this case, ZLAQR4 checks the input parameters and estimates the optimal workspace size for the given values of N, ILO and IHI. The estimate is returned in WORK(1). No error message related to LWORK is issued by XERBLA. Neither H nor Z are accessed.

param.name: info
param.pre: = 0: successful exit > 0: if INFO = i, ZLAQR4 failed to compute all of the eigenvalues. Elements 1:ilo-1 and i+1:n of WR and WI contain those eigenvalues which have been successfully computed. (Failures are rare.) If INFO > 0 and WANT is .FALSE., then on exit, the remaining unconverged eigenvalues are the eigen- values of the upper Hessenberg matrix rows and columns ILO through INFO of the final, output value of H. If INFO > 0 and WANTT is .TRUE., then on exit (*) (initial value of H)*U = U*(final value of H) where U is a unitary matrix. The final value of H is upper Hessenberg and triangular in rows and columns INFO+1 through IHI. If INFO > 0 and WANTZ is .TRUE., then on exit (final value of Z(ILO:IHI,ILOZ:IHIZ) = (initial value of Z(ILO:IHI,ILOZ:IHIZ)*U where U is the unitary matrix in (*) (regard- less of the value of WANTT.) If INFO > 0 and WANTZ is .FALSE., then Z is not accessed.

para.pre: It is a complete implementation of the small bulge multi-shift QR algorithm. It may be called by ZLAQR0 and, for large enough deflation window size, it may be called by ZLAQR3. This subroutine is identical to ZLAQR0 except that it calls ZLAQR2 instead of ZLAQR3. ZLAQR4 computes the eigenvalues of a Hessenberg matrix H and, optionally, the matrices T and Z from the Schur decomposition H = Z T ZH, where T is an upper triangular matrix (the Schur form), and Z is the unitary matrix of Schur vectors. Optionally Z may be postmultiplied into an input unitary matrix Q so that this routine can give the Schur factorization of a matrix A which has been reduced to the Hessenberg form H by the unitary matrix Q: A = Q*H*QH = (QZ)*H*(QZ)**H.

remarks.para: Karen Braman and Ralph Byers, Department of Mathematics, University of Kansas, USA
K. Braman, R. Byers and R. Mathias, The Multi-Shift QR Algorithm Part I: Maintaining Well Focused Shifts, and Level 3 Performance, SIAM Journal of Matrix Analysis, volume 23, pages 929--947, 2002.
K. Braman, R. Byers and R. Mathias, The Multi-Shift QR Algorithm Part II: Aggressive Early Deflation, SIAM Journal of Matrix Analysis, volume 23, pages 948--973, 2002.
Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Early deflation: ZLAQR3 accepts as input an upper Hessenberg matrix H and performs an unitary similarity transformation designed to detect and deflate fully converged eigenvalues from a trailing principal sub-matrix.

param.name: wantt
param.pre: If .TRUE., then the Hessenberg matrix H is fully updated so that the triangular Schur factor may be computed (in cooperation with the calling subroutine). If .FALSE., then only enough of H is updated to preserve the eigenvalues.

param.name: wantz
param.pre: If .TRUE., then the unitary matrix Z is updated so so that the unitary Schur factor may be computed (in cooperation with the calling subroutine). If .FALSE., then Z is not referenced.

param.name: n
param.pre: The order of the matrix H and (if WANTZ is .TRUE.) the order of the unitary matrix Z.

param.name: ktop
param.pre: It is assumed that either KTOP = 1 or H(KTOP,KTOP-1)=0. KBOT and KTOP together determine an isolated block along the diagonal of the Hessenberg matrix.

param.name: kbot
param.pre: It is assumed without a check that either KBOT = N or H(KBOT+1,KBOT)=0. KBOT and KTOP together determine an isolated block along the diagonal of the Hessenberg matrix.

param.name: nw
param.pre: Deflation window size. 1 <= NW <= (KBOT-KTOP+1).

param.name: h
param.pre: H is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (LDH,N) On input the initial N-by-N section of H stores the Hessenberg matrix undergoing aggressive early deflation. On return H has been transformed by a unitary similarity transformation, perturbed, and the returned to Hessenberg form that (it is to be hoped) has some zero sub-diagonal entries.
LDH is integer Leading dimension of H just as declared in the calling subroutine. N <= LDH

param.name: ihiz
param.pre: Specify the rows of Z to which transformations must be applied if WANTZ is .TRUE.. 1 <= ILOZ <= IHIZ <= N.

param.name: z
param.pre: Z is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (LDZ,N) IF WANTZ is .TRUE., then On return, the unitary similarity transformation mentioned above has been accumulated into Z(ILOZ:IHIZ,ILO:IHI) from the right. If WANTZ is .FALSE., then Z is unreferenced.
LDZ is integer The leading dimension of Z just as declared in the calling subroutine. 1 <= LDZ.

param.name: ns
param.pre: NS is integer The number of unconverged (ie approximate) eigenvalues returned in SR and SI that may be used as shifts by the calling subroutine.

param.name: nd
param.pre: ND is integer The number of converged eigenvalues uncovered by this subroutine.

param.name: sh
param.pre: SH is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension KBOT On return, approximate eigenvalues that may be used for shifts are stored in SH(KBOT-ND-NS+1) through SR(KBOT-ND). Converged eigenvalues are stored in SH(KBOT-ND+1) through SH(KBOT).

param.name: v
param.pre: V is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (LDV,NW) An NW-by-NW work array.
LDV is integer scalar The leading dimension of V just as declared in the calling subroutine. NW <= LDV

param.name: nh
param.pre: NH is integer scalar The number of columns of T. NH >= NW.

param.name: t
param.pre: T is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (LDT,NW)
LDT is integer The leading dimension of T just as declared in the calling subroutine. NW <= LDT

param.name: nv
param.pre: NV is integer The number of rows of work array WV available for workspace. NV >= NW.

param.name: wv
param.pre: WV is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (LDWV,NW)
LDWV is integer The leading dimension of W just as declared in the calling subroutine. NW <= LDV

param.name: work
param.pre: WORK is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension LWORK. On exit, WORK(1) is set to an estimate of the optimal value of LWORK for the given values of N, NW, KTOP and KBOT.

param.name: lwork
param.pre: LWORK is integer The dimension of the work array WORK. LWORK = 2*NW suffices, but greater efficiency may result from larger values of LWORK. If LWORK = -1, then a workspace query is assumed; ZLAQR3 only estimates the optimal workspace size for the given values of N, NW, KTOP and KBOT. The estimate is returned in WORK(1). No error message related to LWORK is issued by XERBLA. Neither H nor Z are accessed.

para.pre: On return H has been over- written by a new Hessenberg matrix that is a perturbation of an unitary similarity transformation of H. It is to be hoped that the final version of H has many zero sub-diagonal entries.

remarks.para: Karen Braman and Ralph Byers, Department of Mathematics, University of Kansas, USA
Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Computes the eigenvalues of a Hessenberg matrix H and, optionally, the matrices T and Z from the Schur decomposition H = Z T ZH, where T is an upper triangular matrix (the Schur form), and Z is the unitary matrix of Schur vectors.

param.name: wantt
param.pre: = .TRUE. : the full Schur form T is required; = .FALSE.: only eigenvalues are required.

param.name: wantz
param.pre: = .TRUE. : the matrix of Schur vectors Z is required; = .FALSE.: Schur vectors are not required.

param.name: n
param.pre: The order of the matrix H. N >= 0.

param.name: ihi
param.pre: It is assumed that H is already upper triangular in rows and columns 1:ILO-1 and IHI+1:N and, if ILO > 1, H(ILO,ILO-1) is zero. ILO and IHI are normally set by a previous call to ZGEBAL, and then passed to ZGEHRD when the matrix output by ZGEBAL is reduced to Hessenberg form. Otherwise, ILO and IHI should be set to 1 and N, respectively. If N > 0, then 1 <= ILO <= IHI <= N. If N = 0, then ILO = 1 and IHI = 0.

param.name: h
param.pre: H is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (LDH,N) On entry, the upper Hessenberg matrix H. On exit, if INFO = 0 and WANTT is .TRUE., then H contains the upper triangular matrix T from the Schur decomposition (the Schur form). If INFO = 0 and WANT is .FALSE., then the contents of H are unspecified on exit. (The output value of H when INFO > 0 is given under the description of INFO below.) This subroutine may explicitly set H(i,j) = 0 for i > j and j = 1, 2, ... ILO-1 or j = IHI+1, IHI+2, ... N.
The leading dimension of the array H. LDH >= max(1,N).

param.name: w
param.pre: W is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (N) The computed eigenvalues of H(ILO:IHI,ILO:IHI) are stored in W(ILO:IHI). If WANTT is .TRUE., then the eigenvalues are stored in the same order as on the diagonal of the Schur form returned in H, with W(i) = H(i,i).

param.name: ihiz
param.pre: Specify the rows of Z to which transformations must be applied if WANTZ is .TRUE.. 1 <= ILOZ <= ILO; IHI <= IHIZ <= N.

param.name: z
param.pre: Z is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (LDZ,IHI) If WANTZ is .FALSE., then Z is not referenced. If WANTZ is .TRUE., then Z(ILO:IHI,ILOZ:IHIZ) is replaced by Z(ILO:IHI,ILOZ:IHIZ)*U where U is the orthogonal Schur factor of H(ILO:IHI,ILO:IHI). (The output value of Z when INFO > 0 is given under the description of INFO below.)
The leading dimension of the array Z. if WANTZ is .TRUE. then LDZ >= MAX(1,IHIZ). Otherwize, LDZ >= 1.

param.name: work
param.pre: WORK is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension LWORK On exit, if LWORK = -1, WORK(1) returns an estimate of the optimal value for LWORK.

param.name: lwork
param.pre: The dimension of the array WORK. LWORK >= max(1,N) is sufficient, but LWORK typically as large as 6*N may be required for optimal performance. A workspace query to determine the optimal workspace size is recommended. If LWORK = -1, then ZLAQR0 does a workspace query. In this case, ZLAQR0 checks the input parameters and estimates the optimal workspace size for the given values of N, ILO and IHI. The estimate is returned in WORK(1). No error message related to LWORK is issued by XERBLA. Neither H nor Z are accessed.

param.name: info
param.pre: = 0: successful exit > 0: if INFO = i, ZLAQR0 failed to compute all of the eigenvalues. Elements 1:ilo-1 and i+1:n of WR and WI contain those eigenvalues which have been successfully computed. (Failures are rare.) If INFO > 0 and WANT is .FALSE., then on exit, the remaining unconverged eigenvalues are the eigen- values of the upper Hessenberg matrix rows and columns ILO through INFO of the final, output value of H. If INFO > 0 and WANTT is .TRUE., then on exit (*) (initial value of H)*U = U*(final value of H) where U is a unitary matrix. The final value of H is upper Hessenberg and triangular in rows and columns INFO+1 through IHI. If INFO > 0 and WANTZ is .TRUE., then on exit (final value of Z(ILO:IHI,ILOZ:IHIZ) = (initial value of Z(ILO:IHI,ILOZ:IHIZ)*U where U is the unitary matrix in (*) (regard- less of the value of WANTT.) If INFO > 0 and WANTZ is .FALSE., then Z is not accessed.

para.pre: Optionally Z may be postmultiplied into an input unitary matrix Q so that this routine can give the Schur factorization of a matrix A which has been reduced to the Hessenberg form H by the unitary matrix Q: A = Q*H*QH = (QZ)*H*(QZ)**H.

remarks.para: Karen Braman and Ralph Byers, Department of Mathematics, University of Kansas, USA
K. Braman, R. Byers and R. Mathias, The Multi-Shift QR Algorithm Part I: Maintaining Well Focused Shifts, and Level 3 Performance, SIAM Journal of Matrix Analysis, volume 23, pages 929--947, 2002.
K. Braman, R. Byers and R. Mathias, The Multi-Shift QR Algorithm Part II: Aggressive Early Deflation, SIAM Journal of Matrix Analysis, volume 23, pages 948--973, 2002.
Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Multiplies the M by N complex matrix A by the real scalar CTO/CFROM.

param.name: type
param.pre: TYPE indices the storage type of the input matrix. = 'G': A is a full matrix. = 'L': A is a lower triangular matrix. = 'U': A is an upper triangular matrix. = 'H': A is an upper Hessenberg matrix. = 'B': A is a symmetric band matrix with lower bandwidth KL and upper bandwidth KU and with the only the lower half stored. = 'Q': A is a symmetric band matrix with lower bandwidth KL and upper bandwidth KU and with the only the upper half stored. = 'Z': A is a band matrix with lower bandwidth KL and upper bandwidth KU. See ZGBTRF for storage details.

param.name: kl
param.pre: The lower bandwidth of A. Referenced only if TYPE = 'B', 'Q' or 'Z'.

param.name: ku
param.pre: The upper bandwidth of A. Referenced only if TYPE = 'B', 'Q' or 'Z'.

param.name: cto
param.pre: The matrix A is multiplied by CTO/CFROM. A(I,J) is computed without over/underflow if the final result CTO*A(I,J)/CFROM can be represented without over/underflow. CFROM must be nonzero.

param.name: m
param.pre: The number of rows of the matrix A. M >= 0.

param.name: n
param.pre: The number of columns of the matrix A. N >= 0.

param.name: a
param.pre: A is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (LDA,N) The matrix to be multiplied by CTO/CFROM. See TYPE for the storage type.
The leading dimension of the array A. LDA >= max(1,M).

param.name: info
param.pre: 0 - successful exit <0 - if INFO = -i, the i-th argument had an illegal value.

para.pre: This is done without over/underflow as long as the final result CTO*A(I,J)/CFROM does not over/underflow. TYPE specifies that A may be full, upper triangular, lower triangular, upper Hessenberg, or banded.

remarks.para: Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Returns the values scl and ssq such that ( scl**2 )*ssq = x( 1 )**2 +.

param.name: n
param.pre: The number of elements to be used from the vector X.

param.name: x
param.pre: X is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (N) The vector x as described above. x( i ) = X( 1 + ( i - 1 )*INCX ), 1 <= i <= n.
The increment between successive values of the vector X. INCX > 0.

param.name: scale
param.pre: On entry, the value scale in the equation above. On exit, SCALE is overwritten with the value scl .

param.name: sumsq
param.pre: On entry, the value sumsq in the equation above. On exit, SUMSQ is overwritten with the value ssq .

para.pre: where x( i ) = abs( X( 1 + ( i - 1 )*INCX ) ). The value of sumsq is assumed to be at least unity and the value of ssq will then satisfy 1.0 .le. ssq .le. ( sumsq + 2*n ). scale is assumed to be non-negative and scl returns the value scl = max( scale, abs( real( x( i ) ) ), abs( aimag( x( i ) ) ) ), i scale and sumsq must be supplied in SCALE and SUMSQ respectively. SCALE and SUMSQ are overwritten by scl and ssq respectively. The routine makes only one pass through the vector X.

remarks.para: Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Returns the value of the one norm, or the Frobenius norm, or the infinity norm, or the element of largest absolute value of a complex matrix A.

param.name: norm
param.pre: Specifies the value to be returned in ZLANGE as described above.

param.name: m
param.pre: The number of rows of the matrix A. M >= 0. When M = 0, ZLANGE is set to zero.

param.name: n
param.pre: The number of columns of the matrix A. N >= 0. When N = 0, ZLANGE is set to zero.

param.name: a
param.pre: A is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (LDA,N) The m by n matrix A.
The leading dimension of the array A. LDA >= max(M,1).

param.name: work
param.pre: Dimension (MAX(1,LWORK)), where LWORK >= M when NORM = 'I'; otherwise, WORK is not referenced.

remarks.pre: ZLANGE = ( max(abs(A(i,j))), NORM = 'M' or 'm' ( ( norm1(A), NORM = '1', 'O' or 'o' ( ( normI(A), NORM = 'I' or 'i' ( ( normF(A), NORM = 'F', 'f', 'E' or 'e' ere norm1 denotes the one norm of a matrix (maximum column sum), ormI denotes the infinity norm of a matrix (maximum row sum) and normF denotes the Frobenius norm of a matrix (square root of sum of squares). Note that max(abs(A(i,j))) is not a consistent matrix norm.
remarks.para: Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Computes a QR factorization with column pivoting of the block A(OFFSET+1:M,1:N).

param.name: m
param.pre: The number of rows of the matrix A. M >= 0.

param.name: n
param.pre: The number of columns of the matrix A. N >= 0.

param.name: offset
param.pre: The number of rows of the matrix A that must be pivoted but no factorized. OFFSET >= 0.

param.name: a
param.pre: A is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (LDA,N) On entry, the M-by-N matrix A. On exit, the upper triangle of block A(OFFSET+1:M,1:N) is the triangular factor obtained; the elements in block A(OFFSET+1:M,1:N) below the diagonal, together with the array TAU, represent the orthogonal matrix Q as a product of elementary reflectors. Block A(1:OFFSET,1:N) has been accordingly pivoted, but no factorized.
The leading dimension of the array A. LDA >= max(1,M).

param.name: jpvt
param.pre: Dimension (N) On entry, if JPVT(i) .ne. 0, the i-th column of A is permuted to the front of A*P (a leading column); if JPVT(i) = 0, the i-th column of A is a free column. On exit, if JPVT(i) = k, then the i-th column of A*P was the k-th column of A.

param.name: tau
param.pre: TAU is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (min(M,N)) The scalar factors of the elementary reflectors.

param.name: vn1
param.pre: Dimension (N) The vector with the partial column norms.

param.name: vn2
param.pre: Dimension (N) The vector with the exact column norms.

param.name: work
param.pre: WORK is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (N)

para.pre: The block A(1:OFFSET,1:N) is accordingly pivoted, but not factorized.

remarks.para: G. Quintana-Orti, Depto. de Informatica, Universidad Jaime I, Spain X. Sun, Computer Science Dept., Duke University, USA
Partial column norm updating strategy modified on April 2011 Z. Drmac and Z. Bujanovic, Dept. of Mathematics, University of Zagreb, Croatia.
LAPACK Working Note 176
Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Computes a step of QR factorization with column pivoting of a complex M-by-N matrix A by using Blas-3.

param.name: m
param.pre: The number of rows of the matrix A. M >= 0.

param.name: n
param.pre: The number of columns of the matrix A. N >= 0

param.name: offset
param.pre: The number of rows of A that have been factorized in previous steps.

param.name: nb
param.pre: The number of columns to factorize.

param.name: kb
param.pre: The number of columns actually factorized.

param.name: a
param.pre: A is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (LDA,N) On entry, the M-by-N matrix A. On exit, block A(OFFSET+1:M,1:KB) is the triangular factor obtained and block A(1:OFFSET,1:N) has been accordingly pivoted, but no factorized. The rest of the matrix, block A(OFFSET+1:M,KB+1:N) has been updated.
The leading dimension of the array A. LDA >= max(1,M).

param.name: jpvt
param.pre: Dimension (N) JPVT(I) = K <==> Column K of the full matrix A has been permuted into position I in AP.

param.name: tau
param.pre: TAU is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (KB) The scalar factors of the elementary reflectors.

param.name: vn1
param.pre: Dimension (N) The vector with the partial column norms.

param.name: vn2
param.pre: Dimension (N) The vector with the exact column norms.

param.name: auxv
param.pre: AUXV is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (NB) Auxiliar vector.

param.name: f
param.pre: F is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (LDF,NB) Matrix FH = L * YH * A.
The leading dimension of the array F. LDF >= max(1,N).

para.pre: It tries to factorize NB columns from A starting from the row OFFSET+1, and updates all of the matrix with Blas-3 xGEMM. In some cases, due to catastrophic cancellations, it cannot factorize NB columns. Hence, the actual number of factorized columns is returned in KB. Block A(1:OFFSET,1:N) is accordingly pivoted, but not factorized.

remarks.para: G. Quintana-Orti, Depto. de Informatica, Universidad Jaime I, Spain X. Sun, Computer Science Dept., Duke University, USA
Partial column norm updating strategy modified on April 2011 Z. Drmac and Z. Bujanovic, Dept. of Mathematics, University of Zagreb, Croatia.
LAPACK Working Note 176
Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Reduces the first NB rows and columns of a complex general m by n matrix A to upper or lower real bidiagonal form by a unitary transformation QH * A * P, and returns the matrices X and Y which are needed to apply the transformation to the unreduced part of A.

param.name: m
param.pre: The number of rows in the matrix A.

param.name: n
param.pre: The number of columns in the matrix A.

param.name: nb
param.pre: The number of leading rows and columns of A to be reduced.

param.name: a
param.pre: A is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (LDA,N) On entry, the m by n general matrix to be reduced. On exit, the first NB rows and columns of the matrix are overwritten; the rest of the array is unchanged. If m >= n, elements on and below the diagonal in the first NB columns, with the array TAUQ, represent the unitary matrix Q as a product of elementary reflectors; and elements above the diagonal in the first NB rows, with the array TAUP, represent the unitary matrix P as a product of elementary reflectors. If m < n, elements below the diagonal in the first NB columns, with the array TAUQ, represent the unitary matrix Q as a product of elementary reflectors, and elements on and above the diagonal in the first NB rows, with the array TAUP, represent the unitary matrix P as a product of elementary reflectors. See Further Details.
The leading dimension of the array A. LDA >= max(1,M).

param.name: d
param.pre: Dimension (NB) The diagonal elements of the first NB rows and columns of the reduced matrix. D(i) = A(i,i).

param.name: e
param.pre: Dimension (NB) The off-diagonal elements of the first NB rows and columns of the reduced matrix.

param.name: tauq
param.pre: TAUQ is COMPLEX*16 array dimension (NB) The scalar factors of the elementary reflectors which represent the unitary matrix Q. See Further Details.

param.name: taup
param.pre: TAUP is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (NB) The scalar factors of the elementary reflectors which represent the unitary matrix P. See Further Details.

param.name: x
param.pre: X is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (LDX,NB) The m-by-nb matrix X required to update the unreduced part of A.
The leading dimension of the array X. LDX >= max(1,M).

param.name: y
param.pre: Y is COMPLEX*16 array, dimension (LDY,NB) The n-by-nb matrix Y required to update the unreduced part of A.
The leading dimension of the array Y. LDY >= max(1,N).

para.pre: If m >= n, A is reduced to upper bidiagonal form; if m < n, to lower bidiagonal form. This is an auxiliary routine called by ZGEBRD

The matrices Q and P are represented as products of elementary reflectors: Q = H(1) H(2) . . . H(nb) and P = G(1) G(2) . . . G(nb) Each H(i) and G(i) has the form: H(i) = I - tauq * v * v**H and G(i) = I - taup * u * u**H where tauq and taup are complex scalars, and v and u are complex vectors. If m >= n, v(1:i-1) = 0, v(i) = 1, and v(i:m) is stored on exit in A(i:m,i); u(1:i) = 0, u(i+1) = 1, and u(i+1:n) is stored on exit in A(i,i+1:n); tauq is stored in TAUQ(i) and taup in TAUP(i). If m < n, v(1:i) = 0, v(i+1) = 1, and v(i+1:m) is stored on exit in A(i+2:m,i); u(1:i-1) = 0, u(i) = 1, and u(i:n) is stored on exit in A(i,i+1:n); tauq is stored in TAUQ(i) and taup in TAUP(i). The elements of the vectors v and u together form the m-by-nb matrix V and the nb-by-n matrix UH which are needed, with X and Y, to apply the transformation to the unreduced part of the matrix, using a block update of the form: A := A - V*YH - X*UH. The contents of A on exit are illustrated by the following examples with nb = 2: m = 6 and n = 5 (m > n): m = 5 and n = 6 (m < n): ( 1 1 u1 u1 u1 ) ( 1 u1 u1 u1 u1 u1 ) ( v1 1 1 u2 u2 ) ( 1 1 u2 u2 u2 u2 ) ( v1 v2 a a a ) ( v1 1 a a a a ) ( v1 v2 a a a ) ( v1 v2 a a a a ) ( v1 v2 a a a ) ( v1 v2 a a a a ) ( v1 v2 a a a ) where a denotes an element of the original matrix which is unchanged, vi denotes an element of the vector defining H(i), and ui an element of the vector defining G(i).

remarks.para: Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Copies all or part of a real two-dimensional matrix A to a complex matrix B.

param.name: uplo

param.name: m

param.name: b

The leading dimension of the array B. LDB >= max(1,M).
