summary.para: Copies all or part of a two-dimensional matrix A to another matrix B.

param.name: uplo
param.pre: Specifies the part of the matrix A to be copied to B. = 'U': Upper triangular part = 'L': Lower triangular part Otherwise: All of the matrix A

param.name: m
param.pre: The number of rows of the matrix A. M >= 0.

param.name: n
param.pre: The number of columns of the matrix A. N >= 0.

param.name: a
param.pre: Dimension (LDA,N) The m by n matrix A. If UPLO = 'U', only the upper triangle or trapezoid is accessed; if UPLO = 'L', only the lower triangle or trapezoid is accessed.
The leading dimension of the array A. LDA >= max(1,M).

param.name: b
param.pre: Dimension (LDB,N) On exit, B = A in the locations specified by UPLO.
The leading dimension of the array B. LDB >= max(1,M).

remarks.para: Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Reduces the first NB columns of A real general n-BY-(n-k+1) matrix A so that elements below the k-th sub-diagonal are zero.

param.name: n
param.pre: The order of the matrix A.

param.name: k
param.pre: The offset for the reduction. Elements below the k-th sub-diagonal in the first NB columns are reduced to zero. K < N.

param.name: nb
param.pre: The number of columns to be reduced.

param.name: a
param.pre: Dimension (LDA,N-K+1) On entry, the n-by-(n-k+1) general matrix A. On exit, the elements on and above the k-th sub-diagonal in the first NB columns are overwritten with the corresponding elements of the reduced matrix; the elements below the k-th sub-diagonal, with the array TAU, represent the matrix Q as a product of elementary reflectors. The other columns of A are unchanged. See Further Details.
The leading dimension of the array A. LDA >= max(1,N).

param.name: tau
param.pre: Dimension (NB) The scalar factors of the elementary reflectors. See Further Details.

param.name: t
param.pre: Dimension (LDT,NB) The upper triangular matrix T.
The leading dimension of the array T. LDT >= NB.

param.name: y
param.pre: Dimension (LDY,NB) The n-by-nb matrix Y.
The leading dimension of the array Y. LDY >= N.

para.pre: The reduction is performed by an orthogonal similarity transformation QT * A * Q. The routine returns the matrices V and T which determine Q as a block reflector I - V*T*VT, and also the matrix Y = A * V * T. This is an auxiliary routine called by DGEHRD.

The matrix Q is represented as a product of nb elementary reflectors Q = H(1) H(2) . . . H(nb). Each H(i) has the form H(i) = I - tau * v * v**T where tau is a real scalar, and v is a real vector with v(1:i+k-1) = 0, v(i+k) = 1; v(i+k+1:n) is stored on exit in A(i+k+1:n,i), and tau in TAU(i). The elements of the vectors v together form the (n-k+1)-by-nb matrix V which is needed, with T and Y, to apply the transformation to the unreduced part of the matrix, using an update of the form: A := (I - V*T*VT) * (A - Y*VT). The contents of A on exit are illustrated by the following example with n = 7, k = 3 and nb = 2: ( a a a a a ) ( a a a a a ) ( a a a a a ) ( h h a a a ) ( v1 h a a a ) ( v1 v2 a a a ) ( v1 v2 a a a ) where a denotes an element of the original matrix A, h denotes a modified element of the upper Hessenberg matrix H, and vi denotes an element of the vector defining H(i). This subroutine is a slight modification of LAPACK-3.0's DLAHRD incorporating improvements proposed by Quintana-Orti and Van de Gejin. Note that the entries of A(1:K,2:NB) differ from those returned by the original LAPACK-3.0's DLAHRD routine. (This subroutine is not backward compatible with LAPACK-3.0's DLAHRD.)

remarks.para: Gregorio Quintana-Orti and Robert van de Geijn, "Improving the performance of reduction to Hessenberg form," ACM Transactions on Mathematical Software, 32(2):180-194, June 2006.
Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Applies a real block reflector H or its transpose HT to a real m by n matrix C, from either the left or the right.

param.name: side
param.pre: = 'L': apply H or HT from the Left = 'R': apply H or HT from the Right

param.name: trans
param.pre: = 'N': apply H (No transpose) = 'T': apply HT (Transpose)

param.name: direct
param.pre: Indicates how H is formed from a product of elementary reflectors = 'F': H = H(1) H(2) . . . H(k) (Forward) = 'B': H = H(k) . . . H(2) H(1) (Backward)

param.name: storev
param.pre: Indicates how the vectors which define the elementary reflectors are stored: = 'C': Columnwise = 'R': Rowwise

param.name: m
param.pre: The number of rows of the matrix C.

param.name: n
param.pre: The number of columns of the matrix C.

param.name: k
param.pre: The order of the matrix T (= the number of elementary reflectors whose product defines the block reflector).

param.name: v
param.pre: Dimension (LDV,K) if STOREV = 'C' (LDV,M) if STOREV = 'R' and SIDE = 'L' (LDV,N) if STOREV = 'R' and SIDE = 'R' The matrix V. See Further Details.

param.name: t
param.pre: Dimension (LDT,K) The triangular k by k matrix T in the representation of the block reflector.
The leading dimension of the array T. LDT >= K.

param.name: c
param.pre: Dimension (LDC,N) On entry, the m by n matrix C. On exit, C is overwritten by H*C or HT*C or C*H or C*HT.
The leading dimension of the array C. LDC >= max(1,M).

param.name: work
param.pre: Dimension (LDWORK,K)

para.pre: The shape of the matrix V and the storage of the vectors which define the H(i) is best illustrated by the following example with n = 5 and k = 3. The elements equal to 1 are not stored; the corresponding array elements are modified but restored on exit. The rest of the array is not used. DIRECT = 'F' and STOREV = 'C': DIRECT = 'F' and STOREV = 'R': V = ( 1 ) V = ( 1 v1 v1 v1 v1 ) ( v1 1 ) ( 1 v2 v2 v2 ) ( v1 v2 1 ) ( 1 v3 v3 ) ( v1 v2 v3 ) ( v1 v2 v3 ) DIRECT = 'B' and STOREV = 'C': DIRECT = 'B' and STOREV = 'R': V = ( v1 v2 v3 ) V = ( v1 v1 1 ) ( v1 v2 v3 ) ( v2 v2 v2 1 ) ( 1 v2 v3 ) ( v3 v3 v3 v3 1 ) ( 1 v3 ) ( 1 )

remarks.para: Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Computes the Schur factorization of a real 2-by-2 non-symmetric matrix in standard form: [ A B ] = [ CS -SN ] [ AA BB ] [ CS SN ] [ C D ] [ SN CS ] [ CC DD ] [-SN CS ] where either 1) CC = 0 so that AA and DD are real eigenvalues of the matrix, or 2) AA = DD and BB*CC < 0, so that AA + or - sqrt(BB*CC) are complex conjugate eigenvalues.

param.name: d
param.pre: On entry, the elements of the input matrix. On exit, they are overwritten by the elements of the standardised Schur form.

param.name: rt2i
param.pre: The real and imaginary parts of the eigenvalues. If the eigenvalues are a complex conjugate pair, RT1I > 0.

param.name: sn
param.pre: Parameters of the rotation matrix.

para.pre: Modified by V. Sima, Research Institute for Informatics, Bucharest, Romania, to reduce the risk of cancellation errors, when computing real eigenvalues, and to ensure, if possible, that abs(RT1R) >= abs(RT2R).

remarks.para: Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Is an auxiliary routine called by DHSEQR to update the eigenvalues and Schur decomposition already computed by DHSEQR, by dealing with the Hessenberg sub-matrix in rows and columns ILO to IHI.

param.name: wantt
param.pre: = .TRUE. : the full Schur form T is required; = .FALSE.: only eigenvalues are required.

param.name: wantz
param.pre: = .TRUE. : the matrix of Schur vectors Z is required; = .FALSE.: Schur vectors are not required.

param.name: n
param.pre: The order of the matrix H. N >= 0.

param.name: ihi
param.pre: It is assumed that H is already upper quasi-triangular in rows and columns IHI+1:N, and that H(ILO,ILO-1) = 0 (unless ILO = 1). DLAHQR works primarily with the Hessenberg sub-matrix in rows and columns ILO to IHI, but applies transformations to all of H if WANTT is .TRUE.. 1 <= ILO <= max(1,IHI); IHI <= N.

param.name: h
param.pre: Dimension (LDH,N) On entry, the upper Hessenberg matrix H. On exit, if INFO is zero and if WANTT is .TRUE., H is upper quasi-triangular in rows and columns ILO:IHI, with any 2-by-2 diagonal blocks in standard form. If INFO is zero and WANTT is .FALSE., the contents of H are unspecified on exit. The output state of H if INFO is nonzero is given below under the description of INFO.
The leading dimension of the array H. LDH >= max(1,N).

param.name: wr
param.pre: Dimension (N)

param.name: wi
param.pre: Dimension (N) The real and imaginary parts, respectively, of the computed eigenvalues ILO to IHI are stored in the corresponding elements of WR and WI. If two eigenvalues are computed as a complex conjugate pair, they are stored in consecutive elements of WR and WI, say the i-th and (i+1)th, with WI(i) > 0 and WI(i+1) < 0. If WANTT is .TRUE., the eigenvalues are stored in the same order as on the diagonal of the Schur form returned in H, with WR(i) = H(i,i), and, if H(i:i+1,i:i+1) is a 2-by-2 diagonal block, WI(i) = sqrt(H(i+1,i)*H(i,i+1)) and WI(i+1) = -WI(i).

param.name: ihiz
param.pre: Specify the rows of Z to which transformations must be applied if WANTZ is .TRUE.. 1 <= ILOZ <= ILO; IHI <= IHIZ <= N.

param.name: z
param.pre: Dimension (LDZ,N) If WANTZ is .TRUE., on entry Z must contain the current matrix Z of transformations accumulated by DHSEQR, and on exit Z has been updated; transformations are applied only to the sub-matrix Z(ILOZ:IHIZ,ILO:IHI). If WANTZ is .FALSE., Z is not referenced.
The leading dimension of the array Z. LDZ >= max(1,N).

param.name: info
param.pre: = 0: successful exit > 0: If INFO = i, DLAHQR failed to compute all the eigenvalues ILO to IHI in a total of 30 iterations per eigenvalue; elements i+1:ihi of WR and WI contain those eigenvalues which have been successfully computed. If INFO > 0 and WANTT is .FALSE., then on exit, the remaining unconverged eigenvalues are the eigenvalues of the upper Hessenberg matrix rows and columns ILO thorugh INFO of the final, output value of H. If INFO > 0 and WANTT is .TRUE., then on exit (*) (initial value of H)*U = U*(final value of H) where U is an orthognal matrix. The final value of H is upper Hessenberg and triangular in rows and columns INFO+1 through IHI. If INFO > 0 and WANTZ is .TRUE., then on exit (final value of Z) = (initial value of Z)*U where U is the orthogonal matrix in (*) (regardless of the value of WANTT.)

para.pre: 02-96 Based on modifications by David Day, Sandia National Laboratory, USA 12-04 Further modifications by Ralph Byers, University of Kansas, USA This is a modified version of DLAHQR from LAPACK version 3.0. It is (1) more robust against overflow and underflow and (2) adopts the more conservative Ahues & Tisseur stopping criterion (LAWN 122, 1997).

remarks.para: Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Initializes an m-by-n matrix A to BETA on the diagonal and ALPHA on the offdiagonals.

param.name: uplo
param.pre: Specifies the part of the matrix A to be set. = 'U': Upper triangular part is set; the strictly lower triangular part of A is not changed. = 'L': Lower triangular part is set; the strictly upper triangular part of A is not changed. Otherwise: All of the matrix A is set.

param.name: m
param.pre: The number of rows of the matrix A. M >= 0.

param.name: n
param.pre: The number of columns of the matrix A. N >= 0.

param.name: alpha
param.pre: The constant to which the offdiagonal elements are to be set.

param.name: beta
param.pre: The constant to which the diagonal elements are to be set.

param.name: a
param.pre: The leading dimension of the array A. LDA >= max(1,M).

remarks.para: Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Forms the triangular factor T of a real block reflector H of order n, which is defined as a product of k elementary reflectors.

param.name: direct
param.pre: Specifies the order in which the elementary reflectors are multiplied to form the block reflector: = 'F': H = H(1) H(2) . . . H(k) (Forward) = 'B': H = H(k) . . . H(2) H(1) (Backward)

param.name: storev
param.pre: Specifies how the vectors which define the elementary reflectors are stored (see also Further Details): = 'C': columnwise = 'R': rowwise

param.name: n
param.pre: The order of the block reflector H. N >= 0.

param.name: k
param.pre: The order of the triangular factor T (= the number of elementary reflectors). K >= 1.

param.name: v
param.pre: Dimension (LDV,K) if STOREV = 'C' (LDV,N) if STOREV = 'R' The matrix V. See further details.
The leading dimension of the array V. If STOREV = 'C', LDV >= max(1,N); if STOREV = 'R', LDV >= K.

param.name: tau
param.pre: Dimension (K) TAU(i) must contain the scalar factor of the elementary reflector H(i).

param.name: t
param.pre: Dimension (LDT,K) The k by k triangular factor T of the block reflector. If DIRECT = 'F', T is upper triangular; if DIRECT = 'B', T is lower triangular. The rest of the array is not used.
The leading dimension of the array T. LDT >= K.

para.pre: If DIRECT = 'F', H = H(1) H(2) . . . H(k) and T is upper triangular; If DIRECT = 'B', H = H(k) . . . H(2) H(1) and T is lower triangular. If STOREV = 'C', the vector which defines the elementary reflector H(i) is stored in the i-th column of the array V, and H = I - V * T * VT If STOREV = 'R', the vector which defines the elementary reflector H(i) is stored in the i-th row of the array V, and H = I - VT * T * V

The shape of the matrix V and the storage of the vectors which define the H(i) is best illustrated by the following example with n = 5 and k = 3. The elements equal to 1 are not stored. DIRECT = 'F' and STOREV = 'C': DIRECT = 'F' and STOREV = 'R': V = ( 1 ) V = ( 1 v1 v1 v1 v1 ) ( v1 1 ) ( 1 v2 v2 v2 ) ( v1 v2 1 ) ( 1 v3 v3 ) ( v1 v2 v3 ) ( v1 v2 v3 ) DIRECT = 'B' and STOREV = 'C': DIRECT = 'B' and STOREV = 'R': V = ( v1 v2 v3 ) V = ( v1 v1 1 ) ( v1 v2 v3 ) ( v2 v2 v2 1 ) ( 1 v2 v3 ) ( v3 v3 v3 v3 1 ) ( 1 v3 ) ( 1 )

remarks.para: Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Returns the values scl and smsq such that ( scl**2 )*smsq = x( 1 )**2 +.

param.name: n
param.pre: The number of elements to be used from the vector X.

param.name: x
param.pre: Dimension (N) The vector for which a scaled sum of squares is computed. x( i ) = X( 1 + ( i - 1 )*INCX ), 1 <= i <= n.
The increment between successive values of the vector X. INCX > 0.

param.name: scale
param.pre: On entry, the value scale in the equation above. On exit, SCALE is overwritten with scl , the scaling factor for the sum of squares.

param.name: sumsq
param.pre: On entry, the value sumsq in the equation above. On exit, SUMSQ is overwritten with smsq , the basic sum of squares from which scl has been factored out.

para.pre: where x( i ) = X( 1 + ( i - 1 )*INCX ). The value of sumsq is assumed to be non-negative and scl returns the value scl = max( scale, abs( x( i ) ) ). scale and sumsq must be supplied in SCALE and SUMSQ and scl and smsq are overwritten on SCALE and SUMSQ respectively. The routine makes only one pass through the vector x.

remarks.para: Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Returns the value of the one norm, or the Frobenius norm, or the infinity norm, or the element of largest absolute value of a real matrix A.

param.name: norm
param.pre: Specifies the value to be returned in DLANGE as described above.

param.name: m
param.pre: The number of rows of the matrix A. M >= 0. When M = 0, DLANGE is set to zero.

param.name: n
param.pre: The number of columns of the matrix A. N >= 0. When N = 0, DLANGE is set to zero.

param.name: a
param.pre: Dimension (LDA,N) The m by n matrix A.
The leading dimension of the array A. LDA >= max(M,1).

param.name: work
param.pre: Dimension (MAX(1,LWORK)), where LWORK >= M when NORM = 'I'; otherwise, WORK is not referenced.

remarks.pre: DLANGE = ( max(abs(A(i,j))), NORM = 'M' or 'm' ( ( norm1(A), NORM = '1', 'O' or 'o' ( ( normI(A), NORM = 'I' or 'i' ( ( normF(A), NORM = 'F', 'f', 'E' or 'e' ere norm1 denotes the one norm of a matrix (maximum column sum), ormI denotes the infinity norm of a matrix (maximum row sum) and normF denotes the Frobenius norm of a matrix (square root of sum of squares). Note that max(abs(A(i,j))) is not a consistent matrix norm.
remarks.para: Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Applies a real elementary reflector H to a real m by n matrix C, from either the left or the right.

param.name: side
param.pre: = 'L': form H * C = 'R': form C * H

param.name: m
param.pre: The number of rows of the matrix C.

param.name: n
param.pre: The number of columns of the matrix C.

param.name: v
param.pre: Dimension (M) if SIDE = 'L' or (N) if SIDE = 'R' The vector v in the representation of H.

param.name: tau
param.pre: The value tau in the representation of H.

param.name: c
param.pre: Dimension (LDC,N) On entry, the m by n matrix C. On exit, C is overwritten by the matrix H * C if SIDE = 'L', or C * H if SIDE = 'R'.
The leading dimension of the array C. LDA >= (1,M).

param.name: work
param.pre: Dimension (N) if SIDE = 'L' or (M) if SIDE = 'R' WORK is not referenced if H has order < 11.

para.pre: H is represented in the form H = I - tau * v * v**T where tau is a real scalar and v is a real vector. If tau = 0, then H is taken to be the unit matrix This version uses inline code if H has order < 11.

remarks.para: Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Generate a plane rotation so that [ CS SN ] .

param.name: f
param.pre: The first component of vector to be rotated.

param.name: g
param.pre: The second component of vector to be rotated.

param.name: cs
param.pre: The cosine of the rotation.

param.name: sn
param.pre: The sine of the rotation.

param.name: r
param.pre: The nonzero component of the rotated vector. rsion has a few statements commented out for thread safety ne parameters are computed on each entry). 10 feb 03, SJH.

para.pre: [ F ] = [ R ] where CS**2 + SN**2 = 1. [ -SN CS ] [ G ] [ 0 ] This is a slower, more accurate version of the BLAS1 routine DROTG, with the following other differences: F and G are unchanged on return. If G=0, then CS=1 and SN=0. If F=0 and (G .ne. 0), then CS=0 and SN=1 without doing any floating point operations (saves work in DBDSQR when there are zeros on the diagonal). If F exceeds G in magnitude, CS will be positive.

remarks.para: Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Solves for the N1 by N2 matrix X, 1 <= N1,N2 <= 2, in op(TL)*X + ISGN*X*op(TR) = SCALE*B, where TL is N1 by N1, TR is N2 by N2, B is N1 by N2, and ISGN = 1 or -1.

param.name: ltranl
param.pre: On entry, LTRANL specifies the op(TL): = .FALSE., op(TL) = TL, = .TRUE., op(TL) = TLT.

param.name: ltranr
param.pre: On entry, LTRANR specifies the op(TR): = .FALSE., op(TR) = TR, = .TRUE., op(TR) = TRT.

param.name: isgn
param.pre: On entry, ISGN specifies the sign of the equation as described before. ISGN may only be 1 or -1.

param.name: n1
param.pre: On entry, N1 specifies the order of matrix TL. N1 may only be 0, 1 or 2.

param.name: n2
param.pre: On entry, N2 specifies the order of matrix TR. N2 may only be 0, 1 or 2.

param.name: tl
param.pre: Dimension (LDTL,2) On entry, TL contains an N1 by N1 matrix.
The leading dimension of the matrix TL. LDTL >= max(1,N1).

param.name: tr
param.pre: Dimension (LDTR,2) On entry, TR contains an N2 by N2 matrix.
The leading dimension of the matrix TR. LDTR >= max(1,N2).

param.name: b
param.pre: Dimension (LDB,2) On entry, the N1 by N2 matrix B contains the right-hand side of the equation.
The leading dimension of the matrix B. LDB >= max(1,N1).

param.name: scale
param.pre: On exit, SCALE contains the scale factor. SCALE is chosen less than or equal to 1 to prevent the solution overflowing.

param.name: x
param.pre: Dimension (LDX,2) On exit, X contains the N1 by N2 solution.
The leading dimension of the matrix X. LDX >= max(1,N1).

param.name: xnorm
param.pre: On exit, XNORM is the infinity-norm of the solution.

param.name: info
param.pre: On exit, INFO is set to 0: successful exit. 1: TL and TR have too close eigenvalues, so TL or TR is perturbed to get a nonsingular equation. NOTE: In the interests of speed, this routine does not check the inputs for errors.

para.pre: op(T) = T or TT, where TT denotes the transpose of T.

remarks.para: Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Swaps adjacent diagonal blocks T11 and T22 of order 1 or 2 in an upper quasi-triangular matrix T by an orthogonal similarity transformation.

param.name: wantq
param.pre: = .TRUE. : accumulate the transformation in the matrix Q; = .FALSE.: do not accumulate the transformation.

param.name: n
param.pre: The order of the matrix T. N >= 0.

param.name: t
param.pre: Dimension (LDT,N) On entry, the upper quasi-triangular matrix T, in Schur canonical form. On exit, the updated matrix T, again in Schur canonical form.
The leading dimension of the array T. LDT >= max(1,N).

param.name: q
param.pre: Dimension (LDQ,N) On entry, if WANTQ is .TRUE., the orthogonal matrix Q. On exit, if WANTQ is .TRUE., the updated matrix Q. If WANTQ is .FALSE., Q is not referenced.
The leading dimension of the array Q. LDQ >= 1; and if WANTQ is .TRUE., LDQ >= N.

param.name: j1
param.pre: The index of the first row of the first block T11.

param.name: n1
param.pre: The order of the first block T11. N1 = 0, 1 or 2.

param.name: n2
param.pre: The order of the second block T22. N2 = 0, 1 or 2.

param.name: work
param.pre: Dimension (N)

param.name: info
param.pre: = 0: successful exit = 1: the transformed matrix T would be too far from Schur form; the blocks are not swapped and T and Q are unchanged.

para.pre: T must be in Schur canonical form, that is, block upper triangular with 1-by-1 and 2-by-2 diagonal blocks; each 2-by-2 diagonal block has its diagonal elemnts equal and its off-diagonal elements of opposite sign.

remarks.para: Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Is identical to DLAQR3 except that it avoids recursion by calling DLAHQR instead of DLAQR4.

param.name: wantt
param.pre: If .TRUE., then the Hessenberg matrix H is fully updated so that the quasi-triangular Schur factor may be computed (in cooperation with the calling subroutine). If .FALSE., then only enough of H is updated to preserve the eigenvalues.

param.name: wantz
param.pre: If .TRUE., then the orthogonal matrix Z is updated so so that the orthogonal Schur factor may be computed (in cooperation with the calling subroutine). If .FALSE., then Z is not referenced.

param.name: n
param.pre: The order of the matrix H and (if WANTZ is .TRUE.) the order of the orthogonal matrix Z.

param.name: ktop
param.pre: It is assumed that either KTOP = 1 or H(KTOP,KTOP-1)=0. KBOT and KTOP together determine an isolated block along the diagonal of the Hessenberg matrix.

param.name: kbot
param.pre: It is assumed without a check that either KBOT = N or H(KBOT+1,KBOT)=0. KBOT and KTOP together determine an isolated block along the diagonal of the Hessenberg matrix.

param.name: nw
param.pre: Deflation window size. 1 <= NW <= (KBOT-KTOP+1).

param.name: h
param.pre: Dimension (LDH,N) On input the initial N-by-N section of H stores the Hessenberg matrix undergoing aggressive early deflation. On return H has been transformed by an orthogonal similarity transformation, perturbed, and the returned to Hessenberg form that (it is to be hoped) has some zero sub-diagonal entries.
LDH is integer Leading dimension of H just as declared in the calling subroutine. N <= LDH

param.name: ihiz
param.pre: Specify the rows of Z to which transformations must be applied if WANTZ is .TRUE.. 1 <= ILOZ <= IHIZ <= N.

param.name: z
param.pre: Dimension (LDZ,N) IF WANTZ is .TRUE., then On return, the orthogonal similarity transformation mentioned above has been accumulated into Z(ILOZ:IHIZ,ILO:IHI) from the right. If WANTZ is .FALSE., then Z is unreferenced.
LDZ is integer The leading dimension of Z just as declared in the calling subroutine. 1 <= LDZ.

param.name: ns
param.pre: NS is integer The number of unconverged (ie approximate) eigenvalues returned in SR and SI that may be used as shifts by the calling subroutine.

param.name: nd
param.pre: ND is integer The number of converged eigenvalues uncovered by this subroutine.

param.name: sr
param.pre: Dimension (KBOT)

param.name: si
param.pre: Dimension (KBOT) On return, the real and imaginary parts of approximate eigenvalues that may be used for shifts are stored in SR(KBOT-ND-NS+1) through SR(KBOT-ND) and SI(KBOT-ND-NS+1) through SI(KBOT-ND), respectively. The real and imaginary parts of converged eigenvalues are stored in SR(KBOT-ND+1) through SR(KBOT) and SI(KBOT-ND+1) through SI(KBOT), respectively.

param.name: v
param.pre: Dimension (LDV,NW) An NW-by-NW work array.
LDV is integer scalar The leading dimension of V just as declared in the calling subroutine. NW <= LDV

param.name: nh
param.pre: NH is integer scalar The number of columns of T. NH >= NW.

param.name: t
param.pre: Dimension (LDT,NW)
LDT is integer The leading dimension of T just as declared in the calling subroutine. NW <= LDT

param.name: nv
param.pre: NV is integer The number of rows of work array WV available for workspace. NV >= NW.

param.name: wv
param.pre: Dimension (LDWV,NW)
LDWV is integer The leading dimension of W just as declared in the calling subroutine. NW <= LDV

param.name: work
param.pre: Dimension (LWORK) On exit, WORK(1) is set to an estimate of the optimal value of LWORK for the given values of N, NW, KTOP and KBOT.

param.name: lwork
param.pre: LWORK is integer The dimension of the work array WORK. LWORK = 2*NW suffices, but greater efficiency may result from larger values of LWORK. If LWORK = -1, then a workspace query is assumed; DLAQR2 only estimates the optimal workspace size for the given values of N, NW, KTOP and KBOT. The estimate is returned in WORK(1). No error message related to LWORK is issued by XERBLA. Neither H nor Z are accessed.

para.pre: Aggressive early deflation: This subroutine accepts as input an upper Hessenberg matrix H and performs an orthogonal similarity transformation designed to detect and deflate fully converged eigenvalues from a trailing principal sub-matrix. On return H has been over- written by a new Hessenberg matrix that is a perturbation of an orthogonal similarity transformation of H. It is to be hoped that the final version of H has many zero sub-diagonal entries.

remarks.para: Karen Braman and Ralph Byers, Department of Mathematics, University of Kansas, USA
Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: A 2-by-2 or 3-by-3 matrix H, DLAQR1 sets v to a scalar multiple of the first column of the product (*) K = (H - (sr1 + i*si1)*I)*(H - (sr2 + i*si2)*I) scaling to avoid overflows and most underflows.

param.name: n
param.pre: N is integer Order of the matrix H. N must be either 2 or 3.

param.name: h
param.pre: H is DOUBLE PRECISION array of dimension (LDH,N) The 2-by-2 or 3-by-3 matrix H in (*).
LDH is integer The leading dimension of H as declared in the calling procedure. LDH >= N

param.name: si2
param.pre: The shifts in (*).

param.name: v
param.pre: V is DOUBLE PRECISION array of dimension N A scalar multiple of the first column of the matrix K in (*).

para.pre: It is assumed that either 1) sr1 = sr2 and si1 = -si2 or 2) si1 = si2 = 0. This is useful for starting T implicit shift bulges in the QR algorithm.

remarks.para: Karen Braman and Ralph Byers, Department of Mathematics, University of Kansas, USA
Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Called by DLAQR0, performs a single small-bulge multi-shift QR sweep.

param.name: wantt
param.pre: WANTT is logical scalar WANTT = .true. if the quasi-triangular Schur factor is being computed. WANTT is set to .false. otherwise.

param.name: wantz
param.pre: WANTZ is logical scalar WANTZ = .true. if the orthogonal Schur factor is being computed. WANTZ is set to .false. otherwise.

param.name: kacc22
param.pre: KACC22 is integer with value 0, 1, or 2. Specifies the computation mode of far-from-diagonal orthogonal updates. = 0: DLAQR5 does not accumulate reflections and does not use matrix-matrix multiply to update far-from-diagonal matrix entries. = 1: DLAQR5 accumulates reflections and uses matrix-matrix multiply to update the far-from-diagonal matrix entries. = 2: DLAQR5 accumulates reflections, uses matrix-matrix multiply to update the far-from-diagonal matrix entries, and takes advantage of 2-by-2 block structure during matrix multiplies.

param.name: n
param.pre: N is integer scalar N is the order of the Hessenberg matrix H upon which this subroutine operates.

param.name: ktop
param.pre: KTOP is integer scalar

param.name: kbot
param.pre: KBOT is integer scalar These are the first and last rows and columns of an isolated diagonal block upon which the QR sweep is to be applied. It is assumed without a check that either KTOP = 1 or H(KTOP,KTOP-1) = 0 and either KBOT = N or H(KBOT+1,KBOT) = 0.

param.name: nshfts
param.pre: NSHFTS is integer scalar NSHFTS gives the number of simultaneous shifts. NSHFTS must be positive and even.

param.name: sr
param.pre: SR is DOUBLE PRECISION array of size (NSHFTS)

param.name: si
param.pre: SI is DOUBLE PRECISION array of size (NSHFTS) SR contains the real parts and SI contains the imaginary parts of the NSHFTS shifts of origin that define the multi-shift QR sweep. On return SR and SI may be reordered.

param.name: h
param.pre: H is DOUBLE PRECISION array of size (LDH,N) On input H contains a Hessenberg matrix. On return a multi-shift QR sweep with shifts SR(J)+i*SI(J) is applied to the isolated diagonal block in rows and columns KTOP through KBOT.
LDH is integer scalar LDH is the leading dimension of H just as declared in the calling procedure. LDH >= MAX(1,N).

param.name: ihiz
param.pre: Specify the rows of Z to which transformations must be applied if WANTZ is .TRUE.. 1 <= ILOZ <= IHIZ <= N

param.name: z
param.pre: Z is DOUBLE PRECISION array of size (LDZ,IHI) If WANTZ = .TRUE., then the QR Sweep orthogonal similarity transformation is accumulated into Z(ILOZ:IHIZ,ILO:IHI) from the right. If WANTZ = .FALSE., then Z is unreferenced.
LDZ is integer scalar LDA is the leading dimension of Z just as declared in the calling procedure. LDZ >= N.

param.name: v
param.pre: V is DOUBLE PRECISION array of size (LDV,NSHFTS/2)
LDV is integer scalar LDV is the leading dimension of V as declared in the calling procedure. LDV >= 3.

param.name: u
param.pre: U is DOUBLE PRECISION array of size (LDU,3*NSHFTS-3)
LDU is integer scalar LDU is the leading dimension of U just as declared in the in the calling subroutine. LDU >= 3*NSHFTS-3.

param.name: nh
param.pre: NH is integer scalar NH is the number of columns in array WH available for workspace. NH >= 1.

param.name: wh
param.pre: WH is DOUBLE PRECISION array of size (LDWH,NH)
LDWH is integer scalar Leading dimension of WH just as declared in the calling procedure. LDWH >= 3*NSHFTS-3.

param.name: nv
param.pre: NV is integer scalar NV is the number of rows in WV agailable for workspace. NV >= 1.

param.name: wv
param.pre: WV is DOUBLE PRECISION array of size (LDWV,3*NSHFTS-3)
LDWV is integer scalar LDWV is the leading dimension of WV as declared in the in the calling subroutine. LDWV >= NV.

remarks.para: Karen Braman and Ralph Byers, Department of Mathematics, University of Kansas, USA
K. Braman, R. Byers and R. Mathias, The Multi-Shift QR Algorithm Part I: Maintaining Well Focused Shifts, and Level 3 Performance, SIAM Journal of Matrix Analysis, volume 23, pages 929--947, 2002.
Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Implements one level of recursion for DLAQR0.

param.name: wantt
param.pre: = .TRUE. : the full Schur form T is required; = .FALSE.: only eigenvalues are required.

param.name: wantz
param.pre: = .TRUE. : the matrix of Schur vectors Z is required; = .FALSE.: Schur vectors are not required.

param.name: n
param.pre: The order of the matrix H. N >= 0.

param.name: ihi
param.pre: It is assumed that H is already upper triangular in rows and columns 1:ILO-1 and IHI+1:N and, if ILO > 1, H(ILO,ILO-1) is zero. ILO and IHI are normally set by a previous call to DGEBAL, and then passed to DGEHRD when the matrix output by DGEBAL is reduced to Hessenberg form. Otherwise, ILO and IHI should be set to 1 and N, respectively. If N > 0, then 1 <= ILO <= IHI <= N. If N = 0, then ILO = 1 and IHI = 0.

param.name: h
param.pre: Dimension (LDH,N) On entry, the upper Hessenberg matrix H. On exit, if INFO = 0 and WANTT is .TRUE., then H contains the upper quasi-triangular matrix T from the Schur decomposition (the Schur form); 2-by-2 diagonal blocks (corresponding to complex conjugate pairs of eigenvalues) are returned in standard form, with H(i,i) = H(i+1,i+1) and H(i+1,i)*H(i,i+1) < 0. If INFO = 0 and WANTT is .FALSE., then the contents of H are unspecified on exit. (The output value of H when INFO > 0 is given under the description of INFO below.) This subroutine may explicitly set H(i,j) = 0 for i > j and j = 1, 2, ... ILO-1 or j = IHI+1, IHI+2, ... N.
The leading dimension of the array H. LDH >= max(1,N).

param.name: wr
param.pre: Dimension (IHI)

param.name: wi
param.pre: Dimension (IHI) The real and imaginary parts, respectively, of the computed eigenvalues of H(ILO:IHI,ILO:IHI) are stored in WR(ILO:IHI) and WI(ILO:IHI). If two eigenvalues are computed as a complex conjugate pair, they are stored in consecutive elements of WR and WI, say the i-th and (i+1)th, with WI(i) > 0 and WI(i+1) < 0. If WANTT is .TRUE., then the eigenvalues are stored in the same order as on the diagonal of the Schur form returned in H, with WR(i) = H(i,i) and, if H(i:i+1,i:i+1) is a 2-by-2 diagonal block, WI(i) = sqrt(-H(i+1,i)*H(i,i+1)) and WI(i+1) = -WI(i).

param.name: ihiz
param.pre: Specify the rows of Z to which transformations must be applied if WANTZ is .TRUE.. 1 <= ILOZ <= ILO; IHI <= IHIZ <= N.

param.name: z
param.pre: Dimension (LDZ,IHI) If WANTZ is .FALSE., then Z is not referenced. If WANTZ is .TRUE., then Z(ILO:IHI,ILOZ:IHIZ) is replaced by Z(ILO:IHI,ILOZ:IHIZ)*U where U is the orthogonal Schur factor of H(ILO:IHI,ILO:IHI). (The output value of Z when INFO > 0 is given under the description of INFO below.)
The leading dimension of the array Z. if WANTZ is .TRUE. then LDZ >= MAX(1,IHIZ). Otherwize, LDZ >= 1.

param.name: work
param.pre: Dimension LWORK On exit, if LWORK = -1, WORK(1) returns an estimate of the optimal value for LWORK.

param.name: lwork
param.pre: The dimension of the array WORK. LWORK >= max(1,N) is sufficient, but LWORK typically as large as 6*N may be required for optimal performance. A workspace query to determine the optimal workspace size is recommended. If LWORK = -1, then DLAQR4 does a workspace query. In this case, DLAQR4 checks the input parameters and estimates the optimal workspace size for the given values of N, ILO and IHI. The estimate is returned in WORK(1). No error message related to LWORK is issued by XERBLA. Neither H nor Z are accessed.

param.name: info
param.pre: = 0: successful exit > 0: if INFO = i, DLAQR4 failed to compute all of the eigenvalues. Elements 1:ilo-1 and i+1:n of WR and WI contain those eigenvalues which have been successfully computed. (Failures are rare.) If INFO > 0 and WANT is .FALSE., then on exit, the remaining unconverged eigenvalues are the eigen- values of the upper Hessenberg matrix rows and columns ILO through INFO of the final, output value of H. If INFO > 0 and WANTT is .TRUE., then on exit (*) (initial value of H)*U = U*(final value of H) where U is a orthogonal matrix. The final value of H is upper Hessenberg and triangular in rows and columns INFO+1 through IHI. If INFO > 0 and WANTZ is .TRUE., then on exit (final value of Z(ILO:IHI,ILOZ:IHIZ) = (initial value of Z(ILO:IHI,ILOZ:IHIZ)*U where U is the orthogonal matrix in (*) (regard- less of the value of WANTT.) If INFO > 0 and WANTZ is .FALSE., then Z is not accessed.

para.pre: It is a complete implementation of the small bulge multi-shift QR algorithm. It may be called by DLAQR0 and, for large enough deflation window size, it may be called by DLAQR3. This subroutine is identical to DLAQR0 except that it calls DLAQR2 instead of DLAQR3. DLAQR4 computes the eigenvalues of a Hessenberg matrix H and, optionally, the matrices T and Z from the Schur decomposition H = Z T ZT, where T is an upper quasi-triangular matrix (the Schur form), and Z is the orthogonal matrix of Schur vectors. Optionally Z may be postmultiplied into an input orthogonal matrix Q so that this routine can give the Schur factorization of a matrix A which has been reduced to the Hessenberg form H by the orthogonal matrix Q: A = Q*H*QT = (QZ)*T*(QZ)**T.

remarks.para: Karen Braman and Ralph Byers, Department of Mathematics, University of Kansas, USA
K. Braman, R. Byers and R. Mathias, The Multi-Shift QR Algorithm Part I: Maintaining Well Focused Shifts, and Level 3 Performance, SIAM Journal of Matrix Analysis, volume 23, pages 929--947, 2002.
K. Braman, R. Byers and R. Mathias, The Multi-Shift QR Algorithm Part II: Aggressive Early Deflation, SIAM Journal of Matrix Analysis, volume 23, pages 948--973, 2002.
Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Early deflation: DLAQR3 accepts as input an upper Hessenberg matrix H and performs an orthogonal similarity transformation designed to detect and deflate fully converged eigenvalues from a trailing principal sub-matrix.

param.name: wantt
param.pre: If .TRUE., then the Hessenberg matrix H is fully updated so that the quasi-triangular Schur factor may be computed (in cooperation with the calling subroutine). If .FALSE., then only enough of H is updated to preserve the eigenvalues.

param.name: wantz
param.pre: If .TRUE., then the orthogonal matrix Z is updated so so that the orthogonal Schur factor may be computed (in cooperation with the calling subroutine). If .FALSE., then Z is not referenced.

param.name: n
param.pre: The order of the matrix H and (if WANTZ is .TRUE.) the order of the orthogonal matrix Z.

param.name: ktop
param.pre: It is assumed that either KTOP = 1 or H(KTOP,KTOP-1)=0. KBOT and KTOP together determine an isolated block along the diagonal of the Hessenberg matrix.

param.name: kbot
param.pre: It is assumed without a check that either KBOT = N or H(KBOT+1,KBOT)=0. KBOT and KTOP together determine an isolated block along the diagonal of the Hessenberg matrix.

param.name: nw
param.pre: Deflation window size. 1 <= NW <= (KBOT-KTOP+1).

param.name: h
param.pre: Dimension (LDH,N) On input the initial N-by-N section of H stores the Hessenberg matrix undergoing aggressive early deflation. On return H has been transformed by an orthogonal similarity transformation, perturbed, and the returned to Hessenberg form that (it is to be hoped) has some zero sub-diagonal entries.
LDH is integer Leading dimension of H just as declared in the calling subroutine. N <= LDH

param.name: ihiz
param.pre: Specify the rows of Z to which transformations must be applied if WANTZ is .TRUE.. 1 <= ILOZ <= IHIZ <= N.

param.name: z
param.pre: Dimension (LDZ,N) IF WANTZ is .TRUE., then On return, the orthogonal similarity transformation mentioned above has been accumulated into Z(ILOZ:IHIZ,ILO:IHI) from the right. If WANTZ is .FALSE., then Z is unreferenced.
LDZ is integer The leading dimension of Z just as declared in the calling subroutine. 1 <= LDZ.

param.name: ns
param.pre: NS is integer The number of unconverged (ie approximate) eigenvalues returned in SR and SI that may be used as shifts by the calling subroutine.

param.name: nd
param.pre: ND is integer The number of converged eigenvalues uncovered by this subroutine.

param.name: sr
param.pre: Dimension (KBOT)

param.name: si
param.pre: Dimension (KBOT) On return, the real and imaginary parts of approximate eigenvalues that may be used for shifts are stored in SR(KBOT-ND-NS+1) through SR(KBOT-ND) and SI(KBOT-ND-NS+1) through SI(KBOT-ND), respectively. The real and imaginary parts of converged eigenvalues are stored in SR(KBOT-ND+1) through SR(KBOT) and SI(KBOT-ND+1) through SI(KBOT), respectively.

param.name: v
param.pre: Dimension (LDV,NW) An NW-by-NW work array.
LDV is integer scalar The leading dimension of V just as declared in the calling subroutine. NW <= LDV

param.name: nh
param.pre: NH is integer scalar The number of columns of T. NH >= NW.

param.name: t
param.pre: Dimension (LDT,NW)
LDT is integer The leading dimension of T just as declared in the calling subroutine. NW <= LDT

param.name: nv
param.pre: NV is integer The number of rows of work array WV available for workspace. NV >= NW.

param.name: wv
param.pre: Dimension (LDWV,NW)
LDWV is integer The leading dimension of W just as declared in the calling subroutine. NW <= LDV

param.name: work
param.pre: Dimension (LWORK) On exit, WORK(1) is set to an estimate of the optimal value of LWORK for the given values of N, NW, KTOP and KBOT.

param.name: lwork
param.pre: LWORK is integer The dimension of the work array WORK. LWORK = 2*NW suffices, but greater efficiency may result from larger values of LWORK. If LWORK = -1, then a workspace query is assumed; DLAQR3 only estimates the optimal workspace size for the given values of N, NW, KTOP and KBOT. The estimate is returned in WORK(1). No error message related to LWORK is issued by XERBLA. Neither H nor Z are accessed.

para.pre: On return H has been over- written by a new Hessenberg matrix that is a perturbation of an orthogonal similarity transformation of H. It is to be hoped that the final version of H has many zero sub-diagonal entries.

remarks.para: Karen Braman and Ralph Byers, Department of Mathematics, University of Kansas, USA
Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Computes the eigenvalues of a Hessenberg matrix H and, optionally, the matrices T and Z from the Schur decomposition H = Z T ZT, where T is an upper quasi-triangular matrix (the Schur form), and Z is the orthogonal matrix of Schur vectors.

param.name: wantt
param.pre: = .TRUE. : the full Schur form T is required; = .FALSE.: only eigenvalues are required.

param.name: wantz
param.pre: = .TRUE. : the matrix of Schur vectors Z is required; = .FALSE.: Schur vectors are not required.

param.name: n
param.pre: The order of the matrix H. N >= 0.

param.name: ihi
param.pre: It is assumed that H is already upper triangular in rows and columns 1:ILO-1 and IHI+1:N and, if ILO > 1, H(ILO,ILO-1) is zero. ILO and IHI are normally set by a previous call to DGEBAL, and then passed to DGEHRD when the matrix output by DGEBAL is reduced to Hessenberg form. Otherwise, ILO and IHI should be set to 1 and N, respectively. If N > 0, then 1 <= ILO <= IHI <= N. If N = 0, then ILO = 1 and IHI = 0.

param.name: h
param.pre: Dimension (LDH,N) On entry, the upper Hessenberg matrix H. On exit, if INFO = 0 and WANTT is .TRUE., then H contains the upper quasi-triangular matrix T from the Schur decomposition (the Schur form); 2-by-2 diagonal blocks (corresponding to complex conjugate pairs of eigenvalues) are returned in standard form, with H(i,i) = H(i+1,i+1) and H(i+1,i)*H(i,i+1) < 0. If INFO = 0 and WANTT is .FALSE., then the contents of H are unspecified on exit. (The output value of H when INFO > 0 is given under the description of INFO below.) This subroutine may explicitly set H(i,j) = 0 for i > j and j = 1, 2, ... ILO-1 or j = IHI+1, IHI+2, ... N.
The leading dimension of the array H. LDH >= max(1,N).

param.name: wr
param.pre: Dimension (IHI)

param.name: wi
param.pre: Dimension (IHI) The real and imaginary parts, respectively, of the computed eigenvalues of H(ILO:IHI,ILO:IHI) are stored in WR(ILO:IHI) and WI(ILO:IHI). If two eigenvalues are computed as a complex conjugate pair, they are stored in consecutive elements of WR and WI, say the i-th and (i+1)th, with WI(i) > 0 and WI(i+1) < 0. If WANTT is .TRUE., then the eigenvalues are stored in the same order as on the diagonal of the Schur form returned in H, with WR(i) = H(i,i) and, if H(i:i+1,i:i+1) is a 2-by-2 diagonal block, WI(i) = sqrt(-H(i+1,i)*H(i,i+1)) and WI(i+1) = -WI(i).

param.name: ihiz
param.pre: Specify the rows of Z to which transformations must be applied if WANTZ is .TRUE.. 1 <= ILOZ <= ILO; IHI <= IHIZ <= N.

param.name: z
param.pre: Dimension (LDZ,IHI) If WANTZ is .FALSE., then Z is not referenced. If WANTZ is .TRUE., then Z(ILO:IHI,ILOZ:IHIZ) is replaced by Z(ILO:IHI,ILOZ:IHIZ)*U where U is the orthogonal Schur factor of H(ILO:IHI,ILO:IHI). (The output value of Z when INFO > 0 is given under the description of INFO below.)
The leading dimension of the array Z. if WANTZ is .TRUE. then LDZ >= MAX(1,IHIZ). Otherwize, LDZ >= 1.

param.name: work
param.pre: Dimension LWORK On exit, if LWORK = -1, WORK(1) returns an estimate of the optimal value for LWORK.

param.name: lwork
param.pre: The dimension of the array WORK. LWORK >= max(1,N) is sufficient, but LWORK typically as large as 6*N may be required for optimal performance. A workspace query to determine the optimal workspace size is recommended. If LWORK = -1, then DLAQR0 does a workspace query. In this case, DLAQR0 checks the input parameters and estimates the optimal workspace size for the given values of N, ILO and IHI. The estimate is returned in WORK(1). No error message related to LWORK is issued by XERBLA. Neither H nor Z are accessed.

param.name: info
param.pre: = 0: successful exit > 0: if INFO = i, DLAQR0 failed to compute all of the eigenvalues. Elements 1:ilo-1 and i+1:n of WR and WI contain those eigenvalues which have been successfully computed. (Failures are rare.) If INFO > 0 and WANT is .FALSE., then on exit, the remaining unconverged eigenvalues are the eigen- values of the upper Hessenberg matrix rows and columns ILO through INFO of the final, output value of H. If INFO > 0 and WANTT is .TRUE., then on exit (*) (initial value of H)*U = U*(final value of H) where U is an orthogonal matrix. The final value of H is upper Hessenberg and quasi-triangular in rows and columns INFO+1 through IHI. If INFO > 0 and WANTZ is .TRUE., then on exit (final value of Z(ILO:IHI,ILOZ:IHIZ) = (initial value of Z(ILO:IHI,ILOZ:IHIZ)*U where U is the orthogonal matrix in (*) (regard- less of the value of WANTT.) If INFO > 0 and WANTZ is .FALSE., then Z is not accessed.

para.pre: Optionally Z may be postmultiplied into an input orthogonal matrix Q so that this routine can give the Schur factorization of a matrix A which has been reduced to the Hessenberg form H by the orthogonal matrix Q: A = Q*H*QT = (QZ)*T*(QZ)**T.

remarks.para: Karen Braman and Ralph Byers, Department of Mathematics, University of Kansas, USA
K. Braman, R. Byers and R. Mathias, The Multi-Shift QR Algorithm Part I: Maintaining Well Focused Shifts, and Level 3 Performance, SIAM Journal of Matrix Analysis, volume 23, pages 929--947, 2002.
K. Braman, R. Byers and R. Mathias, The Multi-Shift QR Algorithm Part II: Aggressive Early Deflation, SIAM Journal of Matrix Analysis, volume 23, pages 948--973, 2002.
Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Multiplies the M by N real matrix A by the real scalar CTO/CFROM.

param.name: type
param.pre: TYPE indices the storage type of the input matrix. = 'G': A is a full matrix. = 'L': A is a lower triangular matrix. = 'U': A is an upper triangular matrix. = 'H': A is an upper Hessenberg matrix. = 'B': A is a symmetric band matrix with lower bandwidth KL and upper bandwidth KU and with the only the lower half stored. = 'Q': A is a symmetric band matrix with lower bandwidth KL and upper bandwidth KU and with the only the upper half stored. = 'Z': A is a band matrix with lower bandwidth KL and upper bandwidth KU. See DGBTRF for storage details.

param.name: kl
param.pre: The lower bandwidth of A. Referenced only if TYPE = 'B', 'Q' or 'Z'.

param.name: ku
param.pre: The upper bandwidth of A. Referenced only if TYPE = 'B', 'Q' or 'Z'.

param.name: cto
param.pre: The matrix A is multiplied by CTO/CFROM. A(I,J) is computed without over/underflow if the final result CTO*A(I,J)/CFROM can be represented without over/underflow. CFROM must be nonzero.

param.name: m
param.pre: The number of rows of the matrix A. M >= 0.

param.name: n
param.pre: The number of columns of the matrix A. N >= 0.

param.name: a
param.pre: Dimension (LDA,N) The matrix to be multiplied by CTO/CFROM. See TYPE for the storage type.
The leading dimension of the array A. LDA >= max(1,M).

param.name: info
param.pre: 0 - successful exit <0 - if INFO = -i, the i-th argument had an illegal value.

para.pre: This is done without over/underflow as long as the final result CTO*A(I,J)/CFROM does not over/underflow. TYPE specifies that A may be full, upper triangular, lower triangular, upper Hessenberg, or banded.

remarks.para: Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Performs complex division in real arithmetic a + i*b p + i*q = --------- c + i*d The algorithm is due to Robert L.

param.name: d
param.pre: The scalars a, b, c, and d in the above expression.

param.name: q
param.pre: The scalars p and q in the above expression.

para.pre: Smith and can be found in D. Knuth, The art of Computer Programming, Vol.2, p.195

remarks.para: Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Solves a system of the form (ca A - w D ) X = s B or (ca AT - w D) X = s B with possible scaling ("s") and perturbation of A.

param.name: ltrans
param.pre: =.TRUE.: A-transpose will be used. =.FALSE.: A will be used (not transposed.)

param.name: na
param.pre: The size of the matrix A. It may (only) be 1 or 2.

param.name: nw
param.pre: 1 if "w" is real, 2 if "w" is complex. It may only be 1 or 2.

param.name: smin
param.pre: The desired lower bound on the singular values of A. This should be a safe distance away from underflow or overflow, say, between (underflow/machine precision) and (machine precision * overflow ). (See BIGNUM and ULP.)

param.name: ca
param.pre: The coefficient c, which A is multiplied by.

param.name: a
param.pre: Dimension (LDA,NA) The NA x NA matrix A.
The leading dimension of A. It must be at least NA.

param.name: d1
param.pre: The 1,1 element in the diagonal matrix D.

param.name: d2
param.pre: The 2,2 element in the diagonal matrix D. Not used if NW=1.

param.name: b
param.pre: Dimension (LDB,NW) The NA x NW matrix B (right-hand side). If NW=2 ("w" is complex), column 1 contains the real part of B and column 2 contains the imaginary part.
The leading dimension of B. It must be at least NA.

param.name: wr
param.pre: The real part of the scalar "w".

param.name: wi
param.pre: The imaginary part of the scalar "w". Not used if NW=1.

param.name: x
param.pre: Dimension (LDX,NW) The NA x NW matrix X (unknowns), as computed by DLALN2. If NW=2 ("w" is complex), on exit, column 1 will contain the real part of X and column 2 will contain the imaginary part.
The leading dimension of X. It must be at least NA.

param.name: scale
param.pre: The scale factor that B must be multiplied by to insure that overflow does not occur when computing X. Thus, (ca A - w D) X will be SCALE*B, not B (ignoring perturbations of A.) It will be at most 1.

param.name: xnorm
param.pre: The infinity-norm of X, when X is regarded as an NA x NW real matrix.

param.name: info
param.pre: An error flag. It will be set to zero if no error occurs, a negative number if an argument is in error, or a positive number if ca A - w D had to be perturbed. The possible values are: = 0: No error occurred, and (ca A - w D) did not have to be perturbed. = 1: (ca A - w D) had to be perturbed to make its smallest (or only) singular value greater than SMIN. NOTE: In the interests of speed, this routine does not check the inputs for errors.

para.pre: (AT means A-transpose.) A is an NA x NA real matrix, ca is a real scalar, D is an NA x NA real diagonal matrix, w is a real or complex value, and X and B are NA x 1 matrices -- real if w is real, complex if w is complex. NA may be 1 or 2. If w is complex, X and B are represented as NA x 2 matrices, the first column of each being the real part and the second being the imaginary part. "s" is a scaling factor ( <= 1), computed by DLALN2, which is so chosen that X can be computed without overflow. X is further scaled if necessary to assure that norm(ca A - w D)*norm(X) is less than overflow. If both singular values of (ca A - w D) are less than SMIN, SMIN*identity will be used instead of (ca A - w D). If only one singular value is less than SMIN, one element of (ca A - w D) will be perturbed enough to make the smallest singular value roughly SMIN. If both singular values are at least SMIN, (ca A - w D) will not be perturbed. In any case, the perturbation will be at most some small multiple of max( SMIN, ulp*norm(ca A - w D) ). The singular values are computed by infinity-norm approximations, and thus will only be correct to a factor of 2 or so. Note: all input quantities are assumed to be smaller than overflow by a reasonable factor. (See BIGNUM.)

remarks.para: Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Computes a QR factorization with column pivoting of the block A(OFFSET+1:M,1:N).

param.name: m
param.pre: The number of rows of the matrix A. M >= 0.

param.name: n
param.pre: The number of columns of the matrix A. N >= 0.

param.name: offset
param.pre: The number of rows of the matrix A that must be pivoted but no factorized. OFFSET >= 0.

param.name: a
param.pre: Dimension (LDA,N) On entry, the M-by-N matrix A. On exit, the upper triangle of block A(OFFSET+1:M,1:N) is the triangular factor obtained; the elements in block A(OFFSET+1:M,1:N) below the diagonal, together with the array TAU, represent the orthogonal matrix Q as a product of elementary reflectors. Block A(1:OFFSET,1:N) has been accordingly pivoted, but no factorized.
The leading dimension of the array A. LDA >= max(1,M).

param.name: jpvt
param.pre: Dimension (N) On entry, if JPVT(i) .ne. 0, the i-th column of A is permuted to the front of A*P (a leading column); if JPVT(i) = 0, the i-th column of A is a free column. On exit, if JPVT(i) = k, then the i-th column of A*P was the k-th column of A.

param.name: tau
param.pre: Dimension (min(M,N)) The scalar factors of the elementary reflectors.

param.name: vn1
param.pre: Dimension (N) The vector with the partial column norms.

param.name: vn2
param.pre: Dimension (N) The vector with the exact column norms.

param.name: work
param.pre: Dimension (N)

para.pre: The block A(1:OFFSET,1:N) is accordingly pivoted, but not factorized.

remarks.para: G. Quintana-Orti, Depto. de Informatica, Universidad Jaime I, Spain X. Sun, Computer Science Dept., Duke University, USA
Partial column norm updating strategy modified on April 2011 Z. Drmac and Z. Bujanovic, Dept. of Mathematics, University of Zagreb, Croatia.
LAPACK Working Note 176
Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Computes a step of QR factorization with column pivoting of a real M-by-N matrix A by using Blas-3.

param.name: m
param.pre: The number of rows of the matrix A. M >= 0.

param.name: n
param.pre: The number of columns of the matrix A. N >= 0

param.name: offset
param.pre: The number of rows of A that have been factorized in previous steps.

param.name: nb
param.pre: The number of columns to factorize.

param.name: kb
param.pre: The number of columns actually factorized.

param.name: a
param.pre: Dimension (LDA,N) On entry, the M-by-N matrix A. On exit, block A(OFFSET+1:M,1:KB) is the triangular factor obtained and block A(1:OFFSET,1:N) has been accordingly pivoted, but no factorized. The rest of the matrix, block A(OFFSET+1:M,KB+1:N) has been updated.
The leading dimension of the array A. LDA >= max(1,M).

param.name: jpvt
param.pre: Dimension (N) JPVT(I) = K <==> Column K of the full matrix A has been permuted into position I in AP.

param.name: tau
param.pre: Dimension (KB) The scalar factors of the elementary reflectors.

param.name: vn1
param.pre: Dimension (N) The vector with the partial column norms.

param.name: vn2
param.pre: Dimension (N) The vector with the exact column norms.

param.name: auxv
param.pre: Dimension (NB) Auxiliar vector.

param.name: f
param.pre: Dimension (LDF,NB) Matrix FT = L*YT*A.
The leading dimension of the array F. LDF >= max(1,N).

para.pre: It tries to factorize NB columns from A starting from the row OFFSET+1, and updates all of the matrix with Blas-3 xGEMM. In some cases, due to catastrophic cancellations, it cannot factorize NB columns. Hence, the actual number of factorized columns is returned in KB. Block A(1:OFFSET,1:N) is accordingly pivoted, but not factorized.

remarks.para: G. Quintana-Orti, Depto. de Informatica, Universidad Jaime I, Spain X. Sun, Computer Science Dept., Duke University, USA
Partial column norm updating strategy modified on April 2011 Z. Drmac and Z. Bujanovic, Dept. of Mathematics, University of Zagreb, Croatia.
LAPACK Working Note 176
Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Returns the value of the one norm, or the Frobenius norm, or the infinity norm, or the element of largest absolute value of a real symmetric tridiagonal matrix A.

param.name: norm
param.pre: Specifies the value to be returned in DLANST as described above.

param.name: n
param.pre: The order of the matrix A. N >= 0. When N = 0, DLANST is set to zero.

param.name: d
param.pre: Dimension (N) The diagonal elements of A.

param.name: e
param.pre: Dimension (N-1) The (n-1) sub-diagonal or super-diagonal elements of A.

remarks.pre: DLANST = ( max(abs(A(i,j))), NORM = 'M' or 'm' ( ( norm1(A), NORM = '1', 'O' or 'o' ( ( normI(A), NORM = 'I' or 'i' ( ( normF(A), NORM = 'F', 'f', 'E' or 'e' ere norm1 denotes the one norm of a matrix (maximum column sum), ormI denotes the infinity norm of a matrix (maximum row sum) and normF denotes the Frobenius norm of a matrix (square root of sum of squares). Note that max(abs(A(i,j))) is not a consistent matrix norm.
remarks.para: Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Will create a permutation list which will merge the elements of A (which is composed of two independently sorted sets) into a single set which is sorted in ascending order.

param.name: n2
param.pre: These arguements contain the respective lengths of the two sorted lists to be merged.

param.name: a
param.pre: Dimension (N1+N2) The first N1 elements of A contain a list of numbers which are sorted in either ascending or descending order. Likewise for the final N2 elements.

param.name: dtrd2
param.pre: These are the strides to be taken through the array A. Allowable strides are 1 and -1. They indicate whether a subset of A is sorted in ascending (DTRDx = 1) or descending (DTRDx = -1) order.

param.name: index
param.pre: Dimension (N1+N2) On exit this array will contain a permutation such that if B( I ) = A( INDEX( I ) ) for I=1,N1+N2, then B will be sorted in ascending order.

remarks.para: Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Merges the two sets of singular values together into a single sorted set.

param.name: nl
param.pre: The row dimension of the upper block. NL >= 1.

param.name: nr
param.pre: The row dimension of the lower block. NR >= 1.

param.name: sqre
param.pre: = 0: the lower block is an NR-by-NR square matrix. = 1: the lower block is an NR-by-(NR+1) rectangular matrix. The bidiagonal matrix has N = NL + NR + 1 rows and M = N + SQRE >= N columns.

param.name: k
param.pre: Contains the dimension of the non-deflated matrix, This is the order of the related secular equation. 1 <= K <=N.

param.name: d
param.pre: Dimension(N) On entry D contains the singular values of the two submatrices to be combined. On exit D contains the trailing (N-K) updated singular values (those which were deflated) sorted into increasing order.

param.name: z
param.pre: Dimension(N) On exit Z contains the updating row vector in the secular equation.

param.name: alpha
param.pre: Contains the diagonal element associated with the added row.

param.name: beta
param.pre: Contains the off-diagonal element associated with the added row.

param.name: u
param.pre: Dimension(LDU,N) On entry U contains the left singular vectors of two submatrices in the two square blocks with corners at (1,1), (NL, NL), and (NL+2, NL+2), (N,N). On exit U contains the trailing (N-K) updated left singular vectors (those which were deflated) in its last N-K columns.
The leading dimension of the array U. LDU >= N.

param.name: vt
param.pre: Dimension(LDVT,M) On entry VTT contains the right singular vectors of two submatrices in the two square blocks with corners at (1,1), (NL+1, NL+1), and (NL+2, NL+2), (M,M). On exit VTT contains the trailing (N-K) updated right singular vectors (those which were deflated) in its last N-K columns. In case SQRE =1, the last row of VT spans the right null space.
The leading dimension of the array VT. LDVT >= M.

param.name: dsigma
param.pre: Dimension (N) Contains a copy of the diagonal elements (K-1 singular values and one zero) in the secular equation.

param.name: u2
param.pre: Dimension(LDU2,N) Contains a copy of the first K-1 left singular vectors which will be used by DLASD3 in a matrix multiply (DGEMM) to solve for the new left singular vectors. U2 is arranged into four blocks. The first block contains a column with 1 at NL+1 and zero everywhere else; the second block contains non-zero entries only at and above NL; the third contains non-zero entries only below NL+1; and the fourth is dense.
The leading dimension of the array U2. LDU2 >= N.

param.name: vt2
param.pre: Dimension(LDVT2,N) VT2**T contains a copy of the first K right singular vectors which will be used by DLASD3 in a matrix multiply (DGEMM) to solve for the new right singular vectors. VT2 is arranged into three blocks. The first block contains a row that corresponds to the special 0 diagonal element in SIGMA; the second block contains non-zeros only at and before NL +1; the third block contains non-zeros only at and after NL +2.
The leading dimension of the array VT2. LDVT2 >= M.

param.name: idxp
param.pre: IDXP is INTEGER array dimension(N) This will contain the permutation used to place deflated values of D at the end of the array. On return IDXP(2:K) points to the nondeflated D-values and IDXP(K+1:N) points to the deflated singular values.

param.name: idx
param.pre: IDX is INTEGER array dimension(N) This will contain the permutation used to sort the contents of D into ascending order.

param.name: idxc
param.pre: IDXC is INTEGER array dimension(N) This will contain the permutation used to arrange the columns of the deflated U matrix into three groups: the first group contains non-zero entries only at and above NL, the second contains non-zero entries only below NL+2, and the third is dense.

param.name: idxq
param.pre: IDXQ is INTEGER array dimension(N) This contains the permutation which separately sorts the two sub-problems in D into ascending order. Note that entries in the first hlaf of this permutation must first be moved one position backward; and entries in the second half must first have NL+1 added to their values.

param.name: coltyp
param.pre: COLTYP is INTEGER array dimension(N) As workspace, this will contain a label which will indicate which of the following types a column in the U2 matrix or a row in the VT2 matrix is: 1 : non-zero in the upper half only 2 : non-zero in the lower half only 3 : dense 4 : deflated On exit, it is an array of dimension 4, with COLTYP(I) being the dimension of the I-th type columns.

param.name: info
param.pre: = 0: successful exit. < 0: if INFO = -i, the i-th argument had an illegal value.

para.pre: Then it tries to deflate the size of the problem. There are two ways in which deflation can occur: when two or more singular values are close together or if there is a tiny entry in the Z vector. For each such occurrence the order of the related secular equation problem is reduced by one. DLASD2 is called from DLASD1.

remarks.para: Ming Gu and Huan Ren, Computer Science Division, University of California at Berkeley, USA
Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Computes the positive or negative root (closest to the origin) of z(1) z(2) z(3) f(x) = rho + --------- + ---------- + --------- d(1)-x d(2)-x d(3)-x It is assumed that if ORGATI = .

param.name: kniter
param.pre: Refer to DLAED4 for its significance.

param.name: orgati
param.pre: If ORGATI is true, the needed root is between d(2) and d(3); otherwise it is between d(1) and d(2). See DLAED4 for further details.

param.name: rho
param.pre: Refer to the equation f(x) above.

param.name: d
param.pre: Dimension (3) D satisfies d(1) < d(2) < d(3).

param.name: z
param.pre: Dimension (3) Each of the elements in z must be positive.

param.name: finit
param.pre: The value of f at 0. It is more accurate than the one evaluated inside this routine (if someone wants to do so).

param.name: tau
param.pre: The root of the equation f(x).

param.name: info
param.pre: = 0: successful exit > 0: if INFO = 1, failure to converge

para.pre: true. the root is between d(2) and d(3); otherwise it is between d(1) and d(2) This routine will be called by DLAED4 when necessary. In most cases, the root sought is the smallest in magnitude, though it might not be in some extremely rare situations.

10/02/03: This version has a few statements commented out for thread safety (machine parameters are computed on each entry). SJH. 05/10/06: Modified from a new version of Ren-Cang Li, use Gragg-Thornton-Warner cubic convergent scheme for better stability.

remarks.para: Ren-Cang Li, Computer Science Division, University of California at Berkeley, USA
Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Subroutine computes the square root of the I-th eigenvalue of a positive symmetric rank-one modification of a 2-by-2 diagonal matrix diag( D ) * diag( D ) + RHO * Z * transpose(Z) .

param.name: i
param.pre: The index of the eigenvalue to be computed. I = 1 or I = 2.

param.name: d
param.pre: Dimension ( 2 ) The original eigenvalues. We assume 0 <= D(1) < D(2).

param.name: z
param.pre: Dimension ( 2 ) The components of the updating vector.

param.name: delta
param.pre: Dimension ( 2 ) Contains (D(j) - sigma_I) in its j-th component. The vector DELTA contains the information necessary to construct the eigenvectors.

param.name: rho
param.pre: The scalar in the symmetric updating formula.

param.name: dsigma
param.pre: The computed sigma_I, the I-th updated eigenvalue.

param.name: work
param.pre: Dimension ( 2 ) WORK contains (D(j) + sigma_I) in its j-th component.

para.pre: The diagonal entries in the array D are assumed to satisfy 0 <= D(i) < D(j) for i < j . We also assume RHO > 0 and that the Euclidean norm of the vector Z is one.

remarks.para: Ren-Cang Li, Computer Science Division, University of California at Berkeley, USA
Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Subroutine computes the square root of the I-th updated eigenvalue of a positive symmetric rank-one modification to a positive diagonal matrix whose entries are given as the squares of the corresponding entries in the array d, and that 0 <= D(i) < D(j) for i < j and that RHO > 0.

param.name: n
param.pre: The length of all arrays.

param.name: i
param.pre: The index of the eigenvalue to be computed. 1 <= I <= N.

param.name: d
param.pre: Dimension ( N ) The original eigenvalues. It is assumed that they are in order, 0 <= D(I) < D(J) for I < J.

param.name: z
param.pre: Dimension ( N ) The components of the updating vector.

param.name: delta
param.pre: Dimension ( N ) If N .ne. 1, DELTA contains (D(j) - sigma_I) in its j-th component. If N = 1, then DELTA(1) = 1. The vector DELTA contains the information necessary to construct the (singular) eigenvectors.

param.name: rho
param.pre: The scalar in the symmetric updating formula.

param.name: sigma
param.pre: The computed sigma_I, the I-th updated eigenvalue.

param.name: work
param.pre: Dimension ( N ) If N .ne. 1, WORK contains (D(j) + sigma_I) in its j-th component. If N = 1, then WORK( 1 ) = 1.

param.name: info
param.pre: = 0: successful exit > 0: if INFO = 1, the updating process failed.

para.pre: This is arranged by the calling routine, and is no loss in generality. The rank-one modified system is thus diag( D ) * diag( D ) + RHO * Z * Z_transpose. where we assume the Euclidean norm of Z is 1. The method consists of approximating the rational functions in the secular equation by simpler interpolating rational functions.

remarks.para: Ren-Cang Li, Computer Science Division, University of California at Berkeley, USA
Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Finds all the square roots of the roots of the secular equation, as defined by the values in D and Z.

param.name: nl
param.pre: The row dimension of the upper block. NL >= 1.

param.name: nr
param.pre: The row dimension of the lower block. NR >= 1.

param.name: sqre
param.pre: = 0: the lower block is an NR-by-NR square matrix. = 1: the lower block is an NR-by-(NR+1) rectangular matrix. The bidiagonal matrix has N = NL + NR + 1 rows and M = N + SQRE >= N columns.

param.name: k
param.pre: The size of the secular equation, 1 =< K = < N.

param.name: d
param.pre: Dimension(K) On exit the square roots of the roots of the secular equation, in ascending order.

param.name: q
param.pre: Q is DOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension at least (LDQ,K).
The leading dimension of the array Q. LDQ >= K.

param.name: dsigma
param.pre: Dimension(K) The first K elements of this array contain the old roots of the deflated updating problem. These are the poles of the secular equation.

param.name: u
param.pre: Dimension (LDU, N) The last N - K columns of this matrix contain the deflated left singular vectors.
The leading dimension of the array U. LDU >= N.

param.name: u2
param.pre: Dimension (LDU2, N) The first K columns of this matrix contain the non-deflated left singular vectors for the split problem.
The leading dimension of the array U2. LDU2 >= N.

param.name: vt
param.pre: Dimension (LDVT, M) The last M - K columns of VTT contain the deflated right singular vectors.
The leading dimension of the array VT. LDVT >= N.

param.name: vt2
param.pre: Dimension (LDVT2, N) The first K columns of VT2**T contain the non-deflated right singular vectors for the split problem.
The leading dimension of the array VT2. LDVT2 >= N.

param.name: idxc
param.pre: Dimension ( N ) The permutation used to arrange the columns of U (and rows of VT) into three groups: the first group contains non-zero entries only at and above (or before) NL +1; the second contains non-zero entries only at and below (or after) NL+2; and the third is dense. The first column of U and the row of VT are treated separately, however. The rows of the singular vectors found by DLASD4 must be likewise permuted before the matrix multiplies can take place.

param.name: ctot
param.pre: Dimension ( 4 ) A count of the total number of the various types of columns in U (or rows in VT), as described in IDXC. The fourth column type is any column which has been deflated.

param.name: z
param.pre: Dimension (K) The first K elements of this array contain the components of the deflation-adjusted updating row vector.

param.name: info
param.pre: = 0: successful exit. < 0: if INFO = -i, the i-th argument had an illegal value. > 0: if INFO = 1, a singular value did not converge

para.pre: It makes the appropriate calls to DLASD4 and then updates the singular vectors by matrix multiplication. This code makes very mild assumptions about floating point arithmetic. It will work on machines with a guard digit in add/subtract, or on those binary machines without guard digits which subtract like the Cray XMP, Cray YMP, Cray C 90, or Cray 2. It could conceivably fail on hexadecimal or decimal machines without guard digits, but we know of none. DLASD3 is called from DLASD1.

remarks.para: Ming Gu and Huan Ren, Computer Science Division, University of California at Berkeley, USA
Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Computes the SVD of an upper bidiagonal N-by-M matrix B, where N = NL + NR + 1 and M = N + SQRE.

param.name: nl
param.pre: The row dimension of the upper block. NL >= 1.

param.name: nr
param.pre: The row dimension of the lower block. NR >= 1.

param.name: sqre
param.pre: = 0: the lower block is an NR-by-NR square matrix. = 1: the lower block is an NR-by-(NR+1) rectangular matrix. The bidiagonal matrix has row dimension N = NL + NR + 1, and column dimension M = N + SQRE.

param.name: d
param.pre: D is DOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (N = NL+NR+1). On entry D(1:NL,1:NL) contains the singular values of the upper block; and D(NL+2:N) contains the singular values of the lower block. On exit D(1:N) contains the singular values of the modified matrix.

param.name: alpha
param.pre: Contains the diagonal element associated with the added row.

param.name: beta
param.pre: Contains the off-diagonal element associated with the added row.

param.name: u
param.pre: Dimension(LDU,N) On entry U(1:NL, 1:NL) contains the left singular vectors of the upper block; U(NL+2:N, NL+2:N) contains the left singular vectors of the lower block. On exit U contains the left singular vectors of the bidiagonal matrix.
The leading dimension of the array U. LDU >= max( 1, N ).

param.name: vt
param.pre: Dimension(LDVT,M) where M = N + SQRE. On entry VT(1:NL+1, 1:NL+1)**T contains the right singular vectors of the upper block; VT(NL+2:M, NL+2:M)**T contains the right singular vectors of the lower block. On exit VTT contains the right singular vectors of the bidiagonal matrix.
The leading dimension of the array VT. LDVT >= max( 1, M ).

param.name: idxq
param.pre: Dimension(N) This contains the permutation which will reintegrate the subproblem just solved back into sorted order, i.e. D( IDXQ( I = 1, N ) ) will be in ascending order.

param.name: iwork
param.pre: Dimension( 4 * N )

param.name: work
param.pre: Dimension( 3*M**2 + 2*M )

param.name: info
param.pre: = 0: successful exit. < 0: if INFO = -i, the i-th argument had an illegal value. > 0: if INFO = 1, a singular value did not converge

para.pre: DLASD1 is called from DLASD0. A related subroutine DLASD7 handles the case in which the singular values (and the singular vectors in factored form) are desired. DLASD1 computes the SVD as follows: ( D1(in) 0 0 0 ) B = U(in) * ( Z1**T a Z2**T b ) * VT(in) ( 0 0 D2(in) 0 ) = U(out) * ( D(out) 0) * VT(out) where ZT = (Z1**T a Z2**T b) = u**T VTT, and u is a vector of dimension M with ALPHA and BETA in the NL+1 and NL+2 th entries and zeros elsewhere; and the entry b is empty if SQRE = 0. The left singular vectors of the original matrix are stored in U, and the transpose of the right singular vectors are stored in VT, and the singular values are in D. The algorithm consists of three stages: The first stage consists of deflating the size of the problem when there are multiple singular values or when there are zeros in the Z vector. For each such occurence the dimension of the secular equation problem is reduced by one. This stage is performed by the routine DLASD2. The second stage consists of calculating the updated singular values. This is done by finding the square roots of the roots of the secular equation via the routine DLASD4 (as called by DLASD3). This routine also calculates the singular vectors of the current problem. The final stage consists of computing the updated singular vectors directly using the updated singular values. The singular vectors for the current problem are multiplied with the singular vectors from the overall problem.

remarks.para: Ming Gu and Huan Ren, Computer Science Division, University of California at Berkeley, USA
Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: September 2012

summary.para: Computes the singular values of the 2-by-2 matrix [ F G ] [ 0 H ].

param.name: f
param.pre: The (1,1) element of the 2-by-2 matrix.

param.name: g
param.pre: The (1,2) element of the 2-by-2 matrix.

param.name: h
param.pre: The (2,2) element of the 2-by-2 matrix.

param.name: ssmin
param.pre: The smaller singular value.

param.name: ssmax
param.pre: The larger singular value.

para.pre: On return, SSMIN is the smaller singular value and SSMAX is the larger singular value.

Barring over/underflow, all output quantities are correct to within a few units in the last place (ulps), even in the absence of a guard digit in addition/subtraction. In IEEE arithmetic, the code works correctly if one matrix element is infinite. Overflow will not occur unless the largest singular value itself overflows, or is within a few ulps of overflow. (On machines with partial overflow, like the Cray, overflow may occur if the largest singular value is within a factor of 2 of overflow.) Underflow is harmless if underflow is gradual. Otherwise, results may correspond to a matrix modified by perturbations of size near the underflow threshold.

summary.para: Computes all the eigenvalues of the symmetric positive definite tridiagonal matrix associated with the qd array Z to high relative accuracy are computed to high relative accuracy, in the absence of denormalization, underflow and overflow.

param.name: n
param.pre: he number of rows and columns in the matrix. N >= 0.

param.name: z
param.pre: Dimension ( 4*N ) n entry Z holds the qd array. On exit, entries 1 to N hold the eigenvalues in decreasing order, Z( 2*N+1 ) holds the trace, and Z( 2*N+2 ) holds the sum of the eigenvalues. If N > 2, then Z( 2*N+3 ) holds the iteration count, Z( 2*N+4 ) holds NDIVS/NIN^2, and Z( 2*N+5 ) holds the percentage of shifts that failed.

param.name: info
